B. Tiepolo 11, 34143, Trieste, Italy), BG(University Observatory Munich, Scheinerstrasse 1, 81679, Munich, Germany; Max Planck Institute for Extraterrestrial Physics, Giessenbachstrasse, 85748, Garching, Germany), BH(INAF-Osservatorio Astronomico di Bologna, via Ranzani 1, 40127, Bologna, Italy), BI(University of Vienna, Department of Astrophysics, T\u00fcrkenschanzstr. 17, 1180, Wien, Austria)"], "journal_name": "Astronomy and Astrophysics", "volume": "587", "publication_year": "2016/03/1", "start_page": "A80", "keywords": ["galaxies: clusters: individual: RXC J2248.7-4431", "gravitational lensing: strong", "cosmological parameters", "dark matter", "Astrophysics - Cosmology and Nongalactic Astrophysics", "Astrophysics - Astrophysics of Galaxies"], "url": "https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2016A&A...587A..80C", "abstract": "<BR /> Aims: We perform a comprehensive study of the total mass distribution of the galaxy cluster RXC J2248.7-4431 (z = 0.348) with a set of high-precision strong lensing models, which take advantage of extensive spectroscopic information on many multiply lensed systems. In the effort to understand and quantify inherent systematics in parametric strong lensing modelling, we explore a collection of 22 models in which we use different samples of multiple image families, different parametrizations of the mass distribution and cosmological parameters. <BR /> Methods: As input information for the strong lensing models, we use the Cluster Lensing And Supernova survey with Hubble (CLASH) imaging data and spectroscopic follow-up observations, with the VIsible Multi-Object Spectrograph (VIMOS) and Multi Unit Spectroscopic Explorer (MUSE) on the Very Large Telescope (VLT), to identify and characterize bona fide multiple image families and measure their redshifts down to m<SUB>F814W</SUB> \u2243 26. A total of 16 background sources, over the redshift range 1.0-6.1, are multiply lensed into 47 images, 24 of which are spectroscopically confirmed and belong to ten individual sources. These also include a multiply lensed Lyman-\u03b1 blob at z = 3.118. The cluster total mass distribution and underlying cosmology in the models are optimized by matching the observed positions of the multiple images on the lens plane. Bayesian Markov chain Monte Carlo techniques are used to quantify errors and covariances of the best-fit parameters. <BR /> Results: We show that with a careful selection of a large sample of spectroscopically confirmed multiple images, the best-fit model can reproduce their observed positions with a rms scatter of 0.\u030b3 in a fixed flat \u039bCDM cosmology, whereas the lack of spectroscopic information or the use of inaccurate photometric redshifts can lead to biases in the values of the model parameters. We find that the best-fit parametrization for the cluster total mass distribution is composed of an elliptical pseudo-isothermal mass distribution with a significant core for the overall cluster halo and truncated pseudo-isothermal mass profiles for the cluster galaxies. We show that by adding bona fide photometric-selected multiple images to the sample of spectroscopic families, one can slightly improve constraints on the model parameters. In particular, we find that the degeneracy between the lens total mass distribution and the underlying geometry of the Universe, which is probed via angular diameter distance ratios between the lens and sources and the observer and sources, can be partially removed. Allowing cosmological parameters to vary together with the cluster parameters, we find (at 68% confidence level) \u03a9<SUB>m</SUB> = 0.25<SUP>+ 0.13</SUP><SUB>-0.16</SUB> and w = -1.07<SUP>+ 0.16</SUP><SUB>-0.42</SUB> for a flat \u039bCDM model, and \u03a9<SUB>m</SUB> = 0.31<SUP>+ 0.12</SUP><SUB>-0.13</SUB> and \u03a9<SUB>\u039b</SUB> = 0.38<SUP>+ 0.38</SUP><SUB>-0.27</SUB> for a Universe with w = -1 and free curvature. Finally, using toy models mimicking the overall configuration of multiple images and cluster total mass distribution, we estimate the impact of the line-of-sight mass structure on the positional rms to be 0.\u030b3 \u00b1 0. We argue that the apparent sensitivity of our lensing model to cosmography is due to the combination of the regular potential shape of RXC J2248, a large number of bona fide multiple images out to z = 6.1, and a relatively modest presence of intervening large-scale structure, as revealed by our spectroscopic survey.", "doi": "10.1051/0004-6361/201527670", "custom1": "eprint: arXiv:1512.04555", "issn": "0004-6361"}, "ADS link": "https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2016A&A...587A..80C", "Publisher link via ADS gateway": "https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/link_gateway/2016A&A...587A..80C/PUB_HTML", Ziegler\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_author_institution\" content=\"University of Vienna, Department of Astrophysics, T\u00fcrkenschanzstr. 17, 1180 Wien, Austria\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_title\" content=\"CLASH-VLT: A highly precise strong lensing model of the galaxy cluster RXC J2248.7\u22124431 (Abell S1063) and prospects for cosmography\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_online_date\" content=\"2016/02/22\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_publication_date\" content=\"2016/03/01\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_volume\" content=\"587\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_firstpage\" content=\"A80\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_doi\" content=\"10.1051/0004-6361/201527670\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_bibcode\" content=\"2016A%26A...587A..80C\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_abstract_html_url\" content=\"https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/abs/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_fulltext_html_url\" content=\"https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_pdf_url\" content=\"https://www.aanda.org/articles/aa/pdf/2016/03/aa27670-15.pdf\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_issn\" content=\"0004-6361\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_issn\" content=\"1432-0746\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_language\" content=\"en\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"galaxies: clusters: individual: RXC J2248.7-4431\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"gravitational lensing: strong\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"cosmological parameters\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_keyword\" content=\"dark matter\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_article_type\" content=\"Research Article\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_abstract\" lang=\"en\" content=\"&lt;i&gt;Aims. &lt;i/&gt;We perform a comprehensive study of the total mass distribution of the galaxy cluster RXC J2248.7\u22124431 (&lt;i&gt;z&lt;i/&gt; = 0.348) with a set of high-precision strong lensing models, which take advantage of extensive spectroscopic information on many multiply lensed systems. In the effort to understand and quantify inherent systematics in parametric strong lensing modelling, we explore a collection of 22 models in which we use different samples of multiple image families, different parametrizations of the mass distribution and cosmological parameters.&lt;i&gt;Methods. &lt;i/&gt;As input information for the strong lensing models, we use the Cluster Lensing And Supernova survey with &lt;i&gt;Hubble &lt;i/&gt;(CLASH) imaging data and spectroscopic follow-up observations, with the VIsible Multi-Object Spectrograph (VIMOS) and Multi Unit Spectroscopic Explorer (MUSE) on the Very Large Telescope (VLT), to identify and characterize bona fide multiple image families and measure their redshifts down to &lt;i&gt;m&lt;i/&gt;&lt;sub&gt;F814W&lt;sub/&gt; \u2243 26. A total of 16 background sources, over the redshift range 1.0\u22126.1, are multiply lensed into 47 images, 24 of which are spectroscopically confirmed and belong to ten individual sources. These also include a multiply lensed Lyman-&lt;i&gt;\u03b1&lt;i/&gt; blob at &lt;i&gt;z&lt;i/&gt; = 3.118. The cluster total mass distribution and underlying cosmology in the models are optimized by matching the observed positions of the multiple images on the lens plane. Bayesian Markov chain Monte Carlo techniques are used to quantify errors and covariances of the best-fit parameters.&lt;i&gt;Results. &lt;i/&gt;We show that with a careful selection of a large sample of spectroscopically confirmed multiple images, the best-fit model can reproduce their observed positions with a rms scatter of 0.\u030b3 in a fixed flat \u039bCDM cosmology, whereas the lack of spectroscopic information or the use of inaccurate photometric redshifts can lead to biases in the values of the model parameters. We find that the best-fit parametrization for the cluster total mass distribution is composed of an elliptical pseudo-isothermal mass distribution with a significant core for the overall cluster halo and truncated pseudo-isothermal mass profiles for the cluster galaxies. We show that by adding bona fide photometric-selected multiple images to the sample of spectroscopic families, one can slightly improve constraints on the model parameters. In particular, we find that the degeneracy between the lens total mass distribution and the underlying geometry of the Universe, which is probed via angular diameter distance ratios between the lens and sources and the observer and sources, can be partially removed. Allowing cosmological parameters to vary together with the cluster parameters, we find (at 68% confidence level) \u03a9&lt;sub&gt;m&lt;sub/&gt; = 0.25&lt;sup&gt;+ 0.13&lt;sup/&gt;&lt;sub&gt;-0.16&lt;sub/&gt; and &lt;i&gt;w&lt;i/&gt; = \u22121.07&lt;sup&gt;+ 0.16&lt;sup/&gt;&lt;sub&gt;-0.42&lt;sub/&gt; for a flat \u039bCDM model, and \u03a9&lt;sub&gt;m&lt;sub/&gt; = 0.31&lt;sup&gt;+ 0.12&lt;sup/&gt;&lt;sub&gt;-0.13&lt;sub/&gt; and \u03a9&lt;sub&gt;\u039b&lt;sub/&gt; = 0.38&lt;sup&gt;+ 0.38&lt;sup/&gt;&lt;sub&gt;-0.27&lt;sub/&gt; for a Universe with &lt;i&gt;w&lt;i/&gt; = \u22121 and free curvature. Finally, using toy models mimicking the overall configuration of multiple images and cluster total mass distribution, we estimate the impact of the line-of-sight mass structure on the positional rms to be 0.\u030b3 \u00b1 0. We argue that the apparent sensitivity of our lensing model to cosmography is due to the combination of the regular potential shape of RXC J2248, a large number of bona fide multiple images out to &lt;i&gt;z&lt;i/&gt; = 6.1, and a relatively modest presence of intervening large-scale structure, as revealed by our spectroscopic survey.\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_funding_source\" content=\"citation_funder=Coordena\u00e7\u00e3o de Aperfei\u00e7oamento de Pessoal de N\u00edvel Superior; citation_funder_id=http://dx.doi.org/10.13039/501100002322; citation_grant_number=13946/13-7;\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_funding_source\" content=\"citation_funder=Villum Fonden; citation_funder_id=http://dx.doi.org/10.13039/100008398; citation_grant_number=10123;\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_funding_source\" content=\"citation_funder=Financiadora de Estudos e Projetos; citation_funder_id=http://dx.doi.org/10.13039/501100004809; citation_grant_number=01.07.0515.00;\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_funding_source\" content=\"citation_funder=Funda\u00e7\u00e3o Carlos Chagas Filho de Amparo \u00e0 Pesquisa do Estado do Rio de Janeiro; citation_funder_id=http://dx.doi.org/10.13039/501100004586; citation_grant_number=E-26/171.206/2006; citation_grant_number=E-26/110.516/2012;\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_funding_source\" content=\"citation_funder=Istituto Nazionale di Astrofisica; citation_funder_id=http://dx.doi.org/10.13039/501100005184; citation_grant_number=1.05.01.94.02;\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_funding_source\" content=\"citation_funder=National Aeronautics and Space Administration; citation_funder_id=http://dx.doi.org/10.13039/100000104; citation_grant_number=#HST-HF2-51334.001-A;\">\n  <meta name=\"citation_reference\" content=\"citation_author=G. {\n\t        var term = request.term;\n            $.ajax({\n                url: '/index.php',\n                dataType: 'json',\n                method: 'GET',\n                data: {\n                    option: 'com_solr',\n                    task: 'auto_complete',\n                    query: term\n                },\n                success: function (data) {\n                    var suggestions = [];\n                    try {\n                        data.suggest.default[term].suggestions.forEach(function (s) { suggestions.push(s.term)}) } catch (e) {\n                    }\n\n                    callback(suggestions);\n                },\n                error: function (err) {\n                    callback([]);\n                }\n            });\n        };\n\n\t\t$('#search').find('input[name=q]').autocomplete({\n\t\t\tsource: source\n\t\t});\n\t});\n</script>\n\n                          <div class=\"header-cover\">\n                <div valign=\"top\">\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\tIssue\n\t\t\t\t\t</th>\n\t\t<td width=\"10\"></td>\n\t\t<td>\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<div>\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\tA&A\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t</div>\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<div><strong>Volume </strong>587, March 2016\t\t\t\t</div>\n\t\t\t\t\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t</td>\n\t<tr><td colspan=\"3\" ></td></tr>\n\t<tr><td colspan=\"3\" class=\"sep_issue\"></td></tr>\n\t</tr>\n\t\n\t\t\t\t\t\t<tr>\n\t\t\t\t<th>\n\t\t\t\t\tArticle Number\n\t\t\t\t\t</th>\n\t\t\t\t<td></td>\n\t\t\t\t<td>A80</td>\n\t\t\t</tr>\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t<tr>\n\t\t\t\t<th>\n\t\t\t\t\tNumber of page(s)\n\t\t\t\t\t</th>\n\t\t\t\t<td></td>\n\t\t\t\t<td>22</td>\n\t\t\t</tr>\n\t\t\t\t\n\t\t\t<tr>\n\t\t\t<th>Section</th>\n\t\t\t<td></td>\n\t\t\t<td>Cosmology (including clusters of galaxies)</td>\n\t\t</tr>\n\t\t\n\t\t\t<tr>\n\t\t\t<th>DOI</th>\n\t\t\t<td></td>\n\t\t\t<td>\n\t\t\t\t<a href=\"https://doi.org/10.1051/0004-6361/201527670\">\n\t\t\t\t\thttps://doi.org/10.1051/0004-6361/201527670\n\t\t\t\t</a>\n\t\t\t</td>\n\t\t</tr>\n\t\t\n\t\t\t<tr>\n\t\t\t<th>Published online</th>\n\t\t\t<td></td>\n\t\t\t<td>\n\t\t\t\t22 February 2016\n\t\t\t</td>\n\t\t</tr>\n\t\t\n\t\t</table>\n</div>\n\r\n\r\n\r\n<div id=\"article\">\r\n    <!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC \"-//W3C//DTD XHTML 1.0 Transitional//EN\">\n\n<div class=\"menu\" id=\"bloc\"><ul>\n<li><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#top_full\">Top</a></li>\n<li><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#abs\">Abstract</a></li>\n<li><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#S1\">1. Introduction</a></li>\n<li><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#S2\">2. RXC J2248</a></li>\n<li><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#S5\">3. Strong lens modelling</a></li>\n<li><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#S12\">4. Results</a></li>\n<li><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#S16\">5. Line-of-sight mass structure</a></li>\n<li><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#S17\">6. Conclusions</a></li>\n<li><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#ack\">Acknowledgments</a></li>\n<li><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#ref\">References</a></li>\n<li><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#tabs\">List of tables</a></li>\n<li><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#figs\">List of figures</a></li>\n</ul></div>\n<div id=\"contenu\">\n<a name=\"top_full\"></a><div id=\"head\">A&amp;A 587, A80 (2016)<h2 class=\"title\">CLASH-VLT: A highly precise strong lensing model  of the galaxy cluster RXC J2248.7<span class=\"simple-math\">&#8722;</span>4431 (Abell S1063)  and prospects for cosmography</h2>\n<div class=\"article-authors\"><p class=\"bold\"><span id=\"aa27670-15-author-1\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201527670&amp;n=1\" class=\"author\">G. B. Caminha</span><sup>1</sup><sup>&#8902;</sup>, <span id=\"aa27670-15-author-2\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201527670&amp;n=2\" class=\"author\">C. Grillo</span><sup>2</sup>, <span id=\"aa27670-15-author-3\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201527670&amp;n=3\" class=\"author\">P. Rosati</span><sup>1</sup>, <span id=\"aa27670-15-author-4\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201527670&amp;n=4\" class=\"author\">I. Balestra</span><sup>3</sup><sup>,4</sup>, <span id=\"aa27670-15-author-5\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201527670&amp;n=5\" class=\"author\">W. Karman</span><sup>5</sup>, <span id=\"aa27670-15-author-6\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201527670&amp;n=6\" class=\"author\">M. Lombardi</span><sup>6</sup>, <span id=\"aa27670-15-author-7\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201527670&amp;n=7\" class=\"author\">A. Mercurio</span><sup>7</sup>, <span id=\"aa27670-15-author-8\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201527670&amp;n=8\" class=\"author\">M. Nonino</span><sup>4</sup>, <span id=\"aa27670-15-author-9\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201527670&amp;n=9\" class=\"author\">P. Tozzi</span><sup>8</sup>, <span id=\"aa27670-15-author-10\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201527670&amp;n=10\" class=\"author\">A. Zitrin</span><sup>9</sup><sup>,<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#FN2\">&#8902;&#8902;</a></sup>, <span id=\"aa27670-15-author-11\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201527670&amp;n=11\" class=\"author\">A. Biviano</span><sup>4</sup>, <span id=\"aa27670-15-author-12\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201527670&amp;n=12\" class=\"author\">M. Girardi</span><sup>4</sup><sup>,&#8201;10</sup>, <span id=\"aa27670-15-author-13\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201527670&amp;n=13\" class=\"author\">A. M. Koekemoer</span><sup>11</sup>, <span id=\"aa27670-15-author-14\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201527670&amp;n=14\" class=\"author\">P. Melchior</span><sup>12</sup><sup>,13</sup>, <span id=\"aa27670-15-author-15\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201527670&amp;n=15\" class=\"author\">M. Meneghetti</span><sup>14</sup><sup>,15</sup>, <span id=\"aa27670-15-author-16\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201527670&amp;n=16\" class=\"author\">E. Munari</span><sup>4</sup><sup>,10</sup>, <span id=\"aa27670-15-author-17\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201527670&amp;n=17\" class=\"author\">S. H. Suyu</span><sup>16</sup>, <span id=\"aa27670-15-author-18\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201527670&amp;n=18\" class=\"author\">K. Umetsu</span><sup>16</sup>, <span id=\"aa27670-15-author-19\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201527670&amp;n=19\" class=\"author\">M. Annunziatella</span><sup>4</sup><sup>,10</sup>, <span id=\"aa27670-15-author-20\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201527670&amp;n=20\" class=\"author\">S. Borgani</span><sup>4</sup><sup>,10</sup>, <span id=\"aa27670-15-author-21\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201527670&amp;n=21\" class=\"author\">T. Broadhurst</span><sup>17</sup>, <span id=\"aa27670-15-author-22\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201527670&amp;n=22\" class=\"author\">K. I. Caputi</span><sup>5</sup>, <span id=\"aa27670-15-author-23\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201527670&amp;n=23\" class=\"author\">D. Coe</span><sup>11</sup>, <span id=\"aa27670-15-author-24\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201527670&amp;n=24\" class=\"author\">C. Delgado-Correal</span><sup>1</sup>, <span id=\"aa27670-15-author-25\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201527670&amp;n=25\" class=\"author\">S. Ettori</span><sup>14</sup><sup>,15</sup>, <span id=\"aa27670-15-author-26\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201527670&amp;n=26\" class=\"author\">A. Fritz</span><sup>18</sup>, <span id=\"aa27670-15-author-27\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201527670&amp;n=27\" class=\"author\">B. Frye</span><sup>19</sup>, <span id=\"aa27670-15-author-28\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201527670&amp;n=28\" class=\"author\">R. Gobat</span><sup>20</sup>, <span id=\"aa27670-15-author-29\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201527670&amp;n=29\" class=\"author\">C. Maier</span><sup>21</sup>, <span id=\"aa27670-15-author-30\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201527670&amp;n=30\" class=\"author\">A. Monna</span><sup>3</sup><sup>,22</sup>, <span id=\"aa27670-15-author-31\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201527670&amp;n=31\" class=\"author\">M. Postman</span><sup>11</sup>, <span id=\"aa27670-15-author-32\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201527670&amp;n=32\" class=\"author\">B. Sartoris</span><sup>10</sup>, <span id=\"aa27670-15-author-33\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201527670&amp;n=33\" class=\"author\">S. Seitz</span><sup>3</sup><sup>,22</sup>, <span id=\"aa27670-15-author-34\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201527670&amp;n=34\" class=\"author\">E. Vanzella</span><sup>14</sup> and <span id=\"aa27670-15-author-35\" data-url=\"/component/author/?dkey=10.1051/0004-6361/201527670&amp;n=35\" class=\"author\">B. Ziegler</span><sup>21</sup></p></div>\n<p class=\"aff\"><sup>1</sup> Dipartimento di Fisica e Scienze della Terra, Universit&#224; degli Studi di Ferrara,  via Saragat 1,  44122   Ferrara,  Italy \n <br><sup>2</sup> Dark Cosmology Centre, Niels Bohr Institute, University of Copenhagen,  Juliane Maries Vej 30,  2100   Copenhagen,  Denmark \n <br><sup>3</sup>  University Observatory Munich,  Scheinerstrasse 1,  81679   Munich,  Germany \n <br><sup>4</sup>  INAF&#8211;Osservatorio Astronomico di Trieste, via G. B. Tiepolo 11,  34143   Trieste,  Italy \n <br><sup>5</sup> Kapteyn Astronomical Institute, University of Groningen,  Postbus 800,  9700 AV   Groningen,  The Netherlands \n <br><sup>6</sup> Dipartimento di Fisica, Universit&#224; degli Studi di Milano,  via Celoria 16,  20133   Milano,  Italy \n <br><sup>7</sup>  INAF&#8211;Osservatorio Astronomico di Capodimonte,  via Moiariello 16,  80131   Napoli,  Italy \n <br><sup>8</sup> INAF&#8211;Osservatorio Astrofisico di Arcetri, Largo E. Fermi,  50125   Firenze,  Italy \n <br><sup>9</sup> Cahill Center for Astronomy and Astrophysics, California Institute of Technology,  MS 249-17,  Pasadena,  CA   91125,  USA \n <br><sup>10</sup> Dipartimento di Fisica, Universit&#224; degli Studi di Trieste, via G. B. Tiepolo 11,  34143   Trieste,  Italy \n <br><sup>11</sup>  Space Telescope Science Institute,  3700 San Martin Drive,  Baltimore,  MD   21208,  USA \n <br><sup>12</sup> Center for Cosmology and Astro-Particle Physics, The Ohio State University,  Columbus,  OH   43210,  USA \n <br><sup>13</sup> Department of Physics, The Ohio State University,  Columbus,  OH   43210,  USA \n <br><sup>14</sup>  INAF&#8211;Osservatorio Astronomico di Bologna,  via Ranzani 1,  40127   Bologna,  Italy \n <br><sup>15</sup>  INFN&#8211;Sezione di Bologna,  viale Berti Pichat 6/2,  40127   Bologna,  Italy \n <br><sup>16</sup> Institute of Astronomy as Astrophysics, Academia Sinica,  PO Box 23-141,  Taipei   10617,  Taiwan \n <br><sup>17</sup> Ikerbasque, Basque Foundation for Science, Alameda Urquijo, 36-5 Plaza Bizkaia,  48011   Bilbao,  Spain \n <br><sup>18</sup> INAF&#8211;Istituto di Astrofisica Spaziale e Fisica cosmica (IASF) Milano, via Bassini 15,  20133   Milano,  Italy \n <br><sup>19</sup> Department of Astronomy/Steward Observatory, University of Arizona,  933 North Cherry Avenue,  Tucson,  AZ   85721,  USA \n <br><sup>20</sup> Laboratoire AIM-Paris-Saclay, CEA/DSM-CNRS-Universit&#233; Paris Diderot, Irfu/Service d&#8217;Astrophysique, CEA Saclay,  Orme des Merisiers,  91191   Gif-sur-Yvette,  France \n <br><sup>21</sup> University of Vienna, Department of Astrophysics, T&#252;rkenschanzstr. 17,  1180   Wien,  Austria \n <br><sup>22</sup>  Max Planck Institute for Extraterrestrial Physics,  Giessenbachstrasse,  85748   Garching,  Germany \n <br></p>\n<p class=\"corresp\">\n          <sup>&#8902;</sup> \n          Corresponding author: G. B. Caminha,  e-mail: <a href=\"mailto:gbcaminha@fe.infn.it\">gbcaminha@fe.infn.it</a>\n        <br></p>\n<p class=\"history\"><span class=\"bold\">Received: </span>30 October 2015<br><span class=\"bold\">Accepted: </span>14 December 2015</p>\n<p class=\"bold\"><a name=\"abs\"></a>Abstract</p>\n        <p><i>Aims. </i>We perform a comprehensive study of the total mass distribution of the galaxy cluster RXC J2248.7<span class=\"simple-math\">&#8722;</span>4431 (<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> = 0.348</span>) with a set of high-precision strong lensing models, which take advantage of extensive spectroscopic information on many multiply lensed systems. In the effort to understand and quantify inherent systematics in parametric strong lensing modelling, we explore a collection of 22 models in which we use different samples of multiple image families, different parametrizations of the mass distribution and cosmological parameters.</p>\n        <p><i>Methods. </i>As input information for the strong lensing models, we use the Cluster Lensing And Supernova survey with <i>Hubble </i>(CLASH) imaging data and spectroscopic follow-up observations, with the VIsible Multi-Object Spectrograph (VIMOS) and Multi Unit Spectroscopic Explorer (MUSE) on the Very Large Telescope (VLT), to identify and characterize bona fide multiple image families and measure their redshifts down to <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>m</i><sub>F814W</sub> &#8771; 26</span>. A total of 16 background sources, over the redshift range <span class=\"simple-math\">1.0&#8722;6.1</span>, are multiply lensed into 47 images, 24 of which are spectroscopically confirmed and belong to ten individual sources. These also include a multiply lensed Lyman-<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#945;</i></span> blob at <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> = 3.118</span>. The cluster total mass distribution and underlying cosmology in the models are optimized by matching the observed positions of the multiple images on the lens plane. Bayesian Markov chain Monte Carlo techniques are used to quantify errors and covariances of the best-fit parameters.</p>\n        <p><i>Results. </i>We show that with a careful selection of a large sample of spectroscopically confirmed multiple images, the best-fit model can reproduce their observed positions with a rms scatter of 0.&#779;3 in a fixed flat <span class=\"simple-math\">&#923;</span>CDM cosmology, whereas the lack of spectroscopic information or the use of inaccurate photometric redshifts can lead to biases in the values of the model parameters. We find that the best-fit parametrization for the cluster total mass distribution is composed of an elliptical pseudo-isothermal mass distribution with a significant core for the overall cluster halo and truncated pseudo-isothermal mass profiles for the cluster galaxies. We show that by adding bona fide photometric-selected multiple images to the sample of spectroscopic families, one can slightly improve constraints on the model parameters. In particular, we find that the degeneracy between the lens total mass distribution and the underlying geometry of the Universe, which is probed via angular diameter distance ratios between the lens and sources and the observer and sources, can be partially removed. Allowing cosmological parameters to vary together with the cluster parameters, we find (at <span class=\"simple-math\">68%</span> confidence level) <span class=\"simple-math\">&#937;<sub>m</sub> = 0.25<sup>+ 0.13</sup></span><span class=\"simple-math\"><sub>-0.16</sub></span> and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>w</i> = &#8722;1.07<sup>+ 0.16</sup></span><span class=\"simple-math\"><sub>-0.42</sub></span> for a flat <span class=\"simple-math\">&#923;</span>CDM model, and <span class=\"simple-math\">&#937;<sub>m</sub> = 0.31<sup>+ 0.12</sup></span><span class=\"simple-math\"><sub>-0.13</sub></span> and <span class=\"simple-math\">&#937;<sub>&#923;</sub> = 0.38<sup>+ 0.38</sup></span><span class=\"simple-math\"><sub>-0.27</sub></span> for a Universe with <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>w</i> = &#8722;1</span> and free curvature. Finally, using toy models mimicking the overall configuration of multiple images and cluster total mass distribution, we estimate the impact of the line-of-sight mass structure on the positional rms to be 0.&#779;3 &#177; 0. We argue that the apparent sensitivity of our lensing model to cosmography is due to the combination of the regular potential shape of RXC J2248, a large number of bona fide multiple images out to <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> = 6.1</span>, and a relatively modest presence of intervening large-scale structure, as revealed by our spectroscopic survey.</p>\n      <div class=\"kword\"><p><span class=\"bold\">Key words: </span>galaxies: clusters: individual: RXC J2248.7-4431 / gravitational lensing: strong / cosmological parameters / dark matter</p></div>\n<div class=\"note\">\n<hr width=\"30%\" align=\"left\">\n<div>\n<a name=\"FN2\"></a><sup>&#8902;&#8902;</sup> <p class=\"ligne\"><i>Hubble </i>Fellow.</p>\n</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<p><i>&#169; ESO, 2016</i></p>\n<h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"S1\"></a>1. Introduction</h2>\n<p>Different cosmological probes agree on the finding that the total energy density of the present Universe is composed of less than 5% ordinary baryonic matter; approximately 20% a poorly understood form of non-relativistic matter, called dark matter; and more than 70% an enigmatic constituent with negative pressure (i.e., with an equation of state of the form <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>P</i> = <i>w&#961;</i></span>, where <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>P</i></span> and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#961;</i></span> are the pressure and the density, respectively, and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>w</i></span> is a negative quantity), called dark energy. This dark energy component can account for the current epoch of accelerating expansion of the Universe (e.g. <a name=\"InR57\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R57\">Riess et al. 1998</a>; <a name=\"InR51\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R51\">Perlmutter et al. 1999</a>; <a name=\"InR11\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R11\">Efstathiou et al. 2002</a>; <a name=\"InR12\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R12\">Eisenstein et al. 2005</a>; <a name=\"InR38\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R38\">Komatsu et al. 2011</a>; <a name=\"InR52\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R52\">Planck Collaboration XVI 2014</a>). </p>\n<p>The combination of both geometrical probes and statistics depending on the cosmic growth of structure, e.g. the cluster mass function or the matter power spectrum, has long been recognized as critical in the effort to measure the global geometry of the Universe and test theories of gravity at the same time. In this context, gravitational lensing is a powerful astrophysical tool that can be used to investigate the global structure of the Universe. The matter distribution at different scales and cosmic epochs can be probed with cosmic shear techniques. Both weak and strong lensing methods are very effective in measuring the mass distribution of dark matter halos on galaxy and cluster scales. In addition, the observed positions and time delays of multiple images of strongly lensed sources are sensitive to the geometry of the Universe. In fact, these observables depend on the angular diameter distances between the observer, lens, and source, and, thereby, one can in principle constrain cosmological parameters as a function of redshift, which describes the relative contributions to the total matter-energy density (see e.g. <a name=\"InR60\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R60\">Schneider et al. 1992</a>). </p>\n<p>On galaxy scales, detailed strong lensing models of background, multiply-imaged quasars (e.g. <a name=\"InR65\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R65\">Suyu et al. 2010</a>, <a name=\"InR67\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R67\">2013</a>) and sources at different redshifts (e.g. <a name=\"InR10\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R10\">Collett &amp; Auger 2014</a>), and analyses of statistically significant samples of strong lenses (e.g. <a name=\"InR21\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R21\">Grillo et al. 2008</a>; <a name=\"InR61\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R61\">Schwab et al. 2010</a>) have shown promising results that can complement those of other cosmographic probes and test their possible unknown systematic effects. On galaxy cluster scales, it has only recently been possible to exploit the observed positions of spectroscopically confirmed families of multiple images to obtain precise measurements of the total mass distributions in the core of these lenses (e.g. <a name=\"InR25\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R25\">Halkola et al. 2008</a>; <a name=\"InR23\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R23\">Grillo et al. 2015b</a>) and the first constraints on cosmological parameters (e.g. <a name=\"InR31\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R31\">Jullo et al. 2010</a>; <a name=\"InR41\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R41\">Maga&#241;a et al. 2015</a>). In the last few years, there has been a significant improvement in the strong lensing modelling of galaxy clusters, based on <i>Hubble </i>Space Telescope (HST) multi-colour imaging, used to identify and measure with high precision the angular positions of the multiple images, and deep spectroscopy, which secures the redshifts of lensed sources and cluster members. </p>\n<p>The HST Multi-Cycle Treasury Program Cluster Lensing And Supernova survey with <i>Hubble </i>(CLASH; P.I.: M. Postman; <a name=\"InR54\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R54\">Postman et al. 2012a</a>) and the Director Discretionary Time programme <i>Hubble </i>Frontier Fields<sup><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#FN10\">1</a></sup> (HFF; P.I.: J. Lotz) have led to the identification of hundreds of multiple images, deflected and distorted by the gravitational fields of massive galaxy clusters. Their apparent positions have been measured with an accuracy lower than an arcsecond and their morphologies well characterized. The spectroscopic redshifts of many of these systems have been obtained as part of a separate Very Large Telescope (VLT) spectroscopic follow-up campaigns with the VIsible Multi-Object Spectrograph (VIMOS; <a name=\"InR40\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R40\">Le F&#232;vre et al. 2003</a>) and the Multi Unit Spectroscopic Explorer (MUSE; <a name=\"InR3\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R3\">Bacon et al. 2010</a>). In particular, the ESO Large Programme 186.A<span class=\"simple-math\">&#8722;</span>0798 (P.I.: P. Rosati; <a name=\"InR58\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R58\">Rosati et al. 2014</a>), the so-called CLASH-VLT project (hereafter just CLASH-VLT), has provided an extensive spectroscopic data set on several of these galaxy cluster lenses. </p>\n<p>In this paper, we focus on the HFF cluster RXC J2248.7<span class=\"simple-math\">&#8722;</span>4431 (or Abell S1063; hereafter RXC J2248), which was part of the CLASH survey. The clusters sample selection and observations are presented in <a name=\"InR42\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R42\">Maughan et al. (2008)</a> and <a name=\"InR17\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R17\">Gilmour et al. (2009)</a>. We take advantage of our CLASH multi-band HST data and extensive spectroscopic information, which we have collected on the cluster members and background lensed sources in this galaxy cluster with the VIMOS and MUSE instruments at the VLT (see <a name=\"InR4\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R4\">Balestra et al. 2013</a>; <a name=\"InR32\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R32\">Karman et al. 2015</a>). Combining the HST and VLT data sets, we develop a highly accurate strong lensing model, which is able to constrain the mass distribution of the lens in the inner region and, at the same time, provides interesting constraints on the cosmological parameters, which are ultimately limited by the intervening large-scale structure along the line of sight and the model assumptions on the mass distribution. </p>\n<p>When not specified, the computations were made considering a flat <span class=\"simple-math\">&#923;CDM</span> cosmology with <span class=\"simple-math\">&#937;<sub>m</sub> = 0.3</span> and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>H</i><sub>0</sub> = 70</span> km&#8201;s<span class=\"simple-math\"><sup>-1</sup></span>&#8201;Mpc<span class=\"simple-math\"><sup>-1</sup></span>. In this cosmology, <span class=\"simple-math\">1&#8242;&#8242;</span> corresponds to a physical scale of <span class=\"simple-math\">4.92 kpc</span> at the cluster redshift (<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i><sub>lens</sub> = 0.348</span>). In all images north is top and east is left. </p>\n<h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"S2\"></a>2. RXC J2248</h2>\n<p>RXC J2248 is a rich galaxy cluster at <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i><sub>lens</sub> = 0.348</span> and was first identified as Abell S1063 in <a name=\"InR1\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R1\">Abell et al. (1989)</a>. The high mass and redshift of RXC J2248 make it a powerful gravitational lens creating several strong lensing features, such as giant arcs, multiple image families and distorted background sources. As detailed in this article, a total of 16 multiple image families, ten of which are spectroscopically confirmed, have been securely identified to date over an area of 2 arcmin<span class=\"simple-math\"><sup>2</sup></span>. RXC J2248 was one of the 25 clusters observed within CLASH (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R54\">Postman et al. 2012a</a>) in 16 filters, from the UV through the near-IR with the ACS and WFC3 cameras on board HST. The full-depth, distortion-corrected HST mosaics in each filter were all produced using procedures similar to those described in <a name=\"InR37\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R37\">Koekemoer et al. (2011)</a>, including additional processing beyond the default calibration pipelines and astrometric alignment across all filters, to a precision better than a few milliarcseconds. </p>\n<p>In Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#F1\">1</a>, we show a colour image of RXC J2248 obtained from the combination of the CLASH ACS and <i>WFC3 </i>filters. The red circles indicate the position of the multiple images with spectroscopic redshift, the magenta circles designate families with no spectroscopic confirmation, while the white circles indicate sources close to cluster members or possibly lensed by line-of-sight mass structures or not secure counter images. The positions of the multiple images are uniformly distributed around the cluster core, providing constraints on the overall cluster mass distribution. Most of the families are composed of two or three multiple images, except for the family at redshift 6.111 (ID 14), which is composed of five identified images (see <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R4\">Balestra et al. 2013</a>; <a name=\"InR46\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R46\">Monna et al. 2014</a>). After the submission of this paper, deeper HST imaging from the HFF programme became available, allowing us to detect a fifth, faint image (ID 14e) close to the BCG (see Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#F8\">6</a>). The spectroscopic confirmation of the redshift of this multiple image will be given in Karman et al. (in prep.). As a result of the late identification of image 14e, we include it in only one strong lensing model, labelled as F1-5th in Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#T4\">4</a>. We anticipate that the high redshift of this source and its multiple image configuration, similar to an Einstein&#8217;s cross, will play an important role in constraining the cluster total mass distribution and the relation between angular diameter distances and redshifts (for more details, see Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#S12\">4</a>). </p>\n<p>\n        \n        <a name=\"F1\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table><tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/F1.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15-fig1_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/F1.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 1</span></a>\n            <p>Colour composite image of RXC J2248 obtained using the 16 HST/ACS and WFC3 filters. Spectroscopically confirmed multiple images are indicated in red; multiple images with no spectroscopic redshift in magenta. White circles indicate sources close to a cluster member, or possibly lensed by line-of-sight structures, or with not secure counter images. These last images are not used in the lens model. More information is provided in Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#T1\">1</a>. The blue circle shows the position of the BCG. The multiple image ID 14e is only used in the model F1-5th; see Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#T4\">4</a>.</p>\n          </td>\n</tr></table></div>\n      </p>\n<p>The total mass distribution of RXC J2248 has been studied with different probes, such as X-ray emission (<a name=\"InR20\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R20\">G&#243;mez et al. 2012</a>) and strong (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R46\">Monna et al. 2014</a>; <a name=\"InR28\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R28\">Johnson et al. 2014</a>; <a name=\"InR56\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R56\">Richard et al. 2014</a>; <a name=\"InR72\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R72\">Zitrin et al. 2015</a>) and weak lensing analyses (<a name=\"InR24\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R24\">Gruen et al. 2013</a>; <a name=\"InR71\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R71\">Umetsu et al. 2014</a>; <a name=\"InR45\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R45\">Merten et al. 2015</a>; <a name=\"InR44\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R44\">Melchior et al. 2015</a>), with generally good agreement between these different techniques. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R20\">G&#243;mez et al. (2012)</a> indicates that the galaxy cluster has undergone a recent off-axis merger, and <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R44\">Melchior et al. (2015)</a> find the cluster to be embedded in a filament with corresponding orientation. However, moderately deep X-ray Chandra observations show an elongated but regular shape, with no evidence of massive substructures in the inner region (see Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#F2\">2</a>). </p>\n<p>\n        \n        <a name=\"F2\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table><tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/F2.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15-fig2_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/F2.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 2</span></a>\n            <p>Colour composite image of RXC J2248 overlaid with the <i>Chandra </i>X-ray contours in white (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R20\">G&#243;mez et al. 2012</a>). Red circles indicate the selected cluster members (see Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#S8\">3.1.2</a>). The magenta circle shows the second brightest cluster member, used as the reference for the normalization of the mass-to-light ratio of the cluster members, i.e. <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>L</i><sub>0</sub></span> in Eq. (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#FD3\">3</a>).</p>\n          </td>\n</tr></table></div>\n      </p>\n<p>Previous strong lensing analyses (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R46\">Monna et al. 2014</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R28\">Johnson et al. 2014</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R56\">Richard et al. 2014</a>) have shown that the cluster total mass distribution of RXC J2248 can be well represented by a single elliptical dark matter halo with the addition of the galaxy cluster members. These studies have suggested that the dark matter halo has a significantly flat core of <span class=\"simple-math\">&#8776;</span>17<span class=\"simple-math\">&#8242;&#8242;</span>. The influence of the BCG during the cluster merging process (e.g. <a name=\"InR39\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R39\">Laporte &amp; White 2015</a>) and baryonic physics effects (e.g. <a name=\"InR68\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R68\">Tollet et al. 2016</a>) can account for the formation of a core in the dark-matter density distribution of clusters and galaxies. However, more simulations should be explored to better characterize these effects in objects with different formation histories and mass scales. </p>\n<p>The regular shape and lens efficiency of RXC J2248, in combination with high quality multi-colour imaging and extensive spectroscopy measurements, makes it a very suitable system for testing high-precision strong lensing modelling of the mass distribution of galaxy clusters with appreciable leverage on the underlying geometry of the Universe. </p>\n<p>Upcoming deeper observations of this cluster via the Grism Lens-Amplified Survey from Space (GLASS; GO-13459; P.I.: T. Treu, <a name=\"InR69\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R69\">Treu et al. 2015</a>), the HFF campaign and MUSE, are expected to further increase the number of identified multiple image families and spectroscopic confirmations. </p>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S3\"></a>2.1. VIMOS observations and data reduction</h3>\n<p>As part of the CLASH-VLT Large programme, the cluster RXC J2248 was observed with the VIMOS spectrograph between June 2013 and May 2015. The VIMOS slit-masks were designed in sets of four pointings with one of the quadrants centred on the cluster core and the other three alternatively displaced in the four directions (NE, NW, SE, SW). A total of 16 masks were observed, 12 with the low-resolution (LR) blue grism, and four with the intermediate-resolution (MR) grism; each mask was observed for either <span class=\"simple-math\">3 &#215; 20</span> or <span class=\"simple-math\">3 &#215; 15</span> min (15 h exposure time in total). Therefore, the final integration times for arcs and other background galaxies varied between 45 min and 4 h. A summary of our VIMOS observations is presented in Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#T2\">2</a>. We used <span class=\"simple-math\">1&#8243;</span>-slits. The LR-blue grism has a spectral resolution of approximately <span class=\"simple-math\">28 &#197;</span> and a wavelength coverage of <span class=\"simple-math\">3700&#8722;6700 &#197;</span>, while the MR grism has a spectral resolution of approximately <span class=\"simple-math\">13 &#197;</span> and it covers the wavelength range <span class=\"simple-math\">4800&#8722;10 000 &#197;</span>. </p>\n<p>We define four quality classes by assigning a quality flag (QF) to each redshift measurement, which indicates the reliability of a redshift estimate. The four quality classes are defined as follows: secure (QF&#8201;=&#8201;3), likely (QF&#8201;=&#8201;2), insecure (QF&#8201;=&#8201;1), and based on single emission line (QF&#8201;=&#8201;9). Duplicate observations of hundreds of sources across the whole survey allow us to quantify the reliability of each quality class as follows: redshifts with QF&#8201;=&#8201;3 are correct with a probability of <span class=\"simple-math\">&gt;</span>99.99%, QF&#8201;=&#8201;9 with <span class=\"simple-math\">~</span>92% probability, QF&#8201;=&#8201;2 with <span class=\"simple-math\">~</span>75% probability, and QF&#8201;=&#8201;1 with <span class=\"simple-math\">&lt;</span>40% probability. In this paper we only consider redshifts with QF&#8201;=&#8201;3, 2, or 9. A total of 3734 reliable redshifts were measured over a field <span class=\"simple-math\">~</span>25 arcmin across, where 1184 are cluster members and 2425 are field galaxies (125 are stars). For a complete description of the data acquisition and reduction, see Balestra et al. (in prep.) and Rosati et al. (in prep.). </p>\n<p>\n          \n          <a name=\"F3\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table><tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/F3.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15-fig3_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/F3.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 3</span></a>\n              <p>VLT/VIMOS spectra of the multiple image systems. <i>Left panels</i>: HST cutouts, 10<span class=\"simple-math\">&#8242;&#8242;</span> across with the position of the VIMOS <span class=\"simple-math\">1&#8242;&#8242;</span>-wide slits and the image ID from Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#T1\">1</a>. One- and two-dimensional spectra are shown on the <i>right </i>with measured redshifts and quality flags, including typical emission and absorption lines.</p>\n            </td>\n</tr></table></div>\n        </p>\n<p>\n          \n          <a name=\"F4\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table><tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/F4.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15-fig4_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/F4.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 3</span></a>\n              <p>continued.</p>\n            </td>\n</tr></table></div>\n        </p>\n<p>\n          \n          <a name=\"F5\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table><tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/F5.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15-fig5_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/F5.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 3</span></a>\n              <p>continued.</p>\n            </td>\n</tr></table></div>\n        </p>\n<p>In Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#F3\">3</a>, we show the spectra of the multiply imaged sources. On the left, we show the HST cutout with the position of the <span class=\"simple-math\">1&#8243;</span>-wide slit of VIMOS. On the right, the one- and two-dimensional spectra with the estimated redshifts and quality flags are shown. All spectra present clear emission lines, ensuring reliable redshifts for most of the measurements, i.e. QF<span class=\"simple-math\">=</span>3, with the exception of the low S/N spectrum of image 8a (QF<span class=\"simple-math\">=</span>9), however, its redshift of <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> = 1.837</span> is confirmed by MUSE observations (see Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#S4\">2.2</a>). </p>\n<p>The positions and redshift values (<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i><sub>spec</sub></span>) of all multiple image families are given in Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#T1\">1</a>; positions and redshift values of magnified sources that are not multiply lensed are given in Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#T3\">3</a>. We also quote the Kron observed magnitudes of each source measured with <i>SExtractor </i>(<a name=\"InR5\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R5\">Bertin &amp; Arnouts 1996</a>) in the <i>F814W </i>filter. We use our strong lensing model F2 (see Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#T4\">4</a> and Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#S12\">4</a>) to compute the best-fit value of the redshift (<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i><sub>model</sub></span>) of all multiply imaged sources not spectroscopically confirmed and to compute the magnification factors (<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>). The value of <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span> is computed for a point-like object at the position of the images. Since the model F2 is not suitable to compute the magnification of the families 8, 11 and multiple image 3b, we quote the magnifications values given by the model that includes all spectroscopically confirmed multiple images (model ID F1a, see Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#T4\">4</a>). For family 11, which presents two multiple images very close to the tangential critical line and the highest offset between the observed and model-predicted positions (<span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15-eq52.png\"></span>), we quote the magnification values at the model-predicted positions. These values are less sensitive to the systematic effects affecting this family and are discussed in Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#S11\">3.4</a>. </p>\n<p>Magnitudes corrected by the magnification factor (<span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15-eq53.png\"></span>) are also estimated. The apparent disagreement in the values of <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15-eq53.png\"></span> of some multiple image families can be the result of the evaluation of <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#956;</i></span>, which is computed in a point and not integrated over the extended image, and the difficulties in the photometric measurement of highly extended images, such as the multiple images of the families 2 and 3. The high magnification efficiency of RXC J2248 allows us to probe spectroscopically the very faint end of the galaxy luminosity function at high redshift with intrinsic unlensed magnitudes extending down to <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>M</i><sub>1600</sub> &#8776; &#8722;15</span>, i.e. approximately 5 mag below <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>M</i><sup>&#8727;</sup></span> (<a name=\"InR8\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R8\">Bouwens et al. 2011</a>). </p>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S4\"></a>2.2. MUSE redshift measurements</h3>\n<p>Observations with the new integral-field spectrograph MUSE on the VLT were conducted in the south-west part of the cluster as part of the MUSE science verification programme (ID 60.A-9345, P.I.: K. Caputi). A 8520 s total exposure was obtained in June 2014 with a seeing of <span class=\"simple-math\">&#8776;</span><span class=\"simple-math\">1&#8243;</span>. The MUSE data cube covers <span class=\"simple-math\">1 &#215; 1</span> arcmin<span class=\"simple-math\"><sup>2</sup></span> with a pixel size of <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15-eq57.png\"></span>, over the wavelength range <span class=\"simple-math\">4750&#8722;9350 &#197;</span>, and with a spectral resolution of <span class=\"simple-math\">&#8776;</span>3000 and a dispersion of <span class=\"simple-math\">1.25 &#197;</span>/pixel. Details on data reduction and results can be found in <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R32\">Karman et al. (2015)</a>. We extracted 1D spectra of the strong lensing features within circles with radius ranging from <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15-eq60.png\"></span> to <span class=\"simple-math\">2&#8243;</span> to minimize the contamination of nearby objects and maximize the signal to noise. In this work, guided by the strong lensing model predictions, we revisited several spectra and measured redshifts of two additional multiple image families not included in the CLASH-VLT data and <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R32\">Karman et al. (2015)</a>. In the Figs. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#F6\">4</a> and <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#F7\">5</a>, we show the MUSE spectra of the multiple images 8a/b and 20a/b. The spectra of both sources 8a and 8b show a pair of emission lines at the same wavelengths, which we identify as the resolved CIII] doublet (<span class=\"simple-math\">1906.7,1908.7 &#197;</span>) at <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> = 1.837</span>. The fact that our lensing models predict these sources to be multiple images at <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i><sub>model</sub> = 1.81 &#177; 0.03</span> lends strong support to this interpretation. Also, the CLASH-VLT spectrum of the source 8a (see Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#F3\">3</a>, 7th panel) shows an (unresolved) emission line, although it has low S/N (QF&#8201;=&#8201;9). </p>\n<p>In Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#F7\">5</a> we show the spectra extracted from apertures around the multiple images 20a/b. The existence of an asymmetric emission line at <span class=\"simple-math\">5007.5 &#197;</span> is clear, which we identify with a <span class=\"simple-math\">Ly<i>&#945;</i></span> emission at redshift 3.118. Inspection of the MUSE data cube around this wavelength reveals an extended low-surface brightness emission around each image. The excellent agreement between the modelled redshift of the compact sources (see Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#T1\">1</a>) and the extended emission shows that both are related. Based on our lensing model, we interpret this diffuse double emission as two multiply imaged Ly<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#945;</i></span> blobs. LABs are commonly found in deep narrowband image surveys (<a name=\"InR15\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R15\">Fynbo et al. 1999</a>; <a name=\"InR63\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R63\">Steidel et al. 2000</a>; <a name=\"InR14\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R14\">Francis et al. 2001</a>; <a name=\"InR50\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R50\">Nilsson et al. 2006</a>), and their Ly<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#945;</i></span> luminosities are in the range <span class=\"simple-math\">10<sup>43</sup>&#8722;10<sup>44</sup> erg / s</span> with sizes up to <span class=\"simple-math\">~</span>100 kpc. Although several mechanisms have been proposed to explain their large luminosities, there is still no consensus on the physical nature of these sources (<a name=\"InR2\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R2\">Arrigoni Battaia et al. 2015</a>, and references therein). A detailed study of this source is presented in <a name=\"InR9\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R9\">Caminha et al. (2015)</a>. </p>\n<p>\n          <a name=\"T1\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><div class=\"ligne\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/T1.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Table 1</span></a>\n              <p> Multiple image systems.</p>\n            </div></div>\n        </p>\n<p>\n          <a name=\"T2\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><div class=\"ligne\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/T2.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Table 2</span></a>\n              <p>Log of VIMOS observations of the Frontier Fields cluster RXC J2248, taken as part of the CLASH-VLT spectroscopic campaign.</p>\n            </div></div>\n        </p>\n<h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"S5\"></a>3. Strong lens modelling</h2>\n<p>We use the strong lensing observables to reconstruct the total mass distribution of RXC J2248. The positions of the multiple images, from a single background source, depend on the relative distances (observer, lens and source) and on the total mass distribution of the intervening lens. We describe our methodology to determine the mass distribution of the cluster from the observed positions of the identified multiple images below. </p>\n<p>First, we visually identify the multiple images on the colour composite HST image (Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#F1\">1</a>). We revisit all the previously suggested multiple image systems and explore new systems during this identification. Using colour and morphological information of these objects and the expected parity from basic principles of gravitational lensing theory, we select luminosity peaks. In a second step, we refine the measurements with the stacked images of the optical (<i>F435W, F606W, F625W, F775W, F814W </i>and <i>F850lp</i>) and near-IR (<i>F105W, F110W, F125W, F140W </i>and <i>F160W</i>) filters, depending on the colour of the multiple images. However, we do not use different stacked images to measure the luminosity peaks of different multiple images belonging to the same family. We draw different iso-luminosity contours around each peak and determine the position of the centroid of the innermost contour enclosing a few pixels (<span class=\"simple-math\">&#8776;</span>5, or 0.1 square arcsec). With this procedure, we ensure that we consider the peaks of the light distribution of different multiple images that correspond to the same position on the source plane, thus avoiding systematics that are often introduced by automated measurements. The measured positions of multiple images are listed in Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#T1\">1</a>. </p>\n<p>\n        <a name=\"T3\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><div class=\"ligne\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/T3.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Table 3</span></a>\n            <p> Magnified but not multiply imaged sources.</p>\n          </div></div>\n      </p>\n<p>Some extended arcs show multiple peaks or knots (e.g. families 2, 4 and 9), thus in principle allowing us to split these families into two subsets, as in <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R46\">Monna et al. (2014)</a>. This technique can improve the constraints on the critical lines close to the multiple images, however, it does not introduce any extra constraint in the overall best-fitting model. In this work, we choose to use only one peak for each family to avoid any possible systematic effect in the modelling and to save computational time. </p>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S6\"></a>3.1. Mass model components</h3>\n<p>The optical and X-ray images of the cluster (see Figs. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#F1\">1</a> and <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#F2\">2</a>) indicate a regular elliptical shape with no evident large asymmetries or massive substructures in the region where multiple images are formed. In view of its regular shape, we consider three main components for the total mass distribution in the lens modelling: 1) a smooth component describing the extended dark matter distribution; 2) the mass distribution of the BCG; and 3) small-scale halos associated with galaxy members. </p>\n<p>We also check whether the presence of an external shear term associated with two mass components in the north-east and south-west of the cluster could improve the overall fit. In these two regions (outside the field of view shown in Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#F1\">1</a>), we notice the presence of bright cluster galaxies that could contribute to the cluster total mass with additional massive dark matter halo terms. However, we do not find any significant improvement in the reconstruction of the observed positions of the multiple images and these components are completely unconstrained. Moreover, we test a model including an extra mass component in the core of the cluster (<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>R</i> &#8818; 300</span> kpc). Also, in this case the fit does not improve significantly to justify the increase in the number of free parameters, for which we obtain best-fitting values that are physically not very plausible. For example, we find an extremely high value for the mass ellipticity of this new term. </p>\n<h4 class=\"sec3\">\n<a name=\"S7\"></a>3.1.1. Dark matter component</h4>\n<p>For the smooth mass component (intra-cluster light, hot gas and, mainly, dark matter) we adopt a pseudo-isothermal elliptical mass distribution (hereafter PIEMD; <a name=\"InR33\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R33\">Kassiola &amp; Kovner 1993</a>). The projected mass density distribution of this model is given by <a name=\"FD1\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15-eq289.png\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(1)</span></span>where <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>R</i>(<i>x,y,&#949;</i>)</span> is an elliptical coordinate on the lens plane and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#963;</i><sub>v</sub></span> is the fiducial velocity dispersion. The ellipticity <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#949;</i></span> is defined as <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#949;</i> &#8801; 1&#8722;<i>b</i>/<i>a</i></span>, where <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>a</i></span> and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>b</i></span> are the semi-major and minor axis, respectively. There are six parameters describing this model: the centre position (<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>x</i><sub>0</sub></span> and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>y</i><sub>0</sub></span>), the ellipticity and its orientation angle (<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#949;</i></span> and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#952;</i></span>, where the horizontal is the principal axis and the angle is counted counterclockwise), the fiducial velocity dispersion (<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#963;</i><sub>v</sub></span>), and the core radius (<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>r</i><sub>core</sub></span>). The PIEMD parametrization has been shown to be a good model to describe cluster mass distributions in strong lensing studies and sometimes provides a better fit than the canonical Navarro-Frenk-White (hereafter NFW; <a name=\"InR48\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R48\">Navarro et al. 1996</a>, <a name=\"InR49\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R49\">1997</a>) mass distribution. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R23\">Grillo et al. (2015b)</a>, using a similar high quality data set, found for example that the dark matter components of the HFF galaxy cluster MACS J0416.1<span class=\"simple-math\">&#8722;</span>2403 are better described by PIEMD models. </p>\n<p>To test the dependence of our main results on a specific mass parametrization, we also consider an NFW distribution for the main dark matter component. In this work, we use a NFW model with elliptical potential (hereafther PNFW; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R33\">Kassiola &amp; Kovner 1993</a>; <a name=\"InR35\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R35\">Kneib 2002</a>; <a name=\"InR18\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R18\">Golse &amp; Kneib 2002</a>), which significantly reduces computing time of the deflection angle across the image in the <i>lenstool </i>implementation. For this model, the free parameters are the characteristic radius <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>r</i><sub><i>s</i></sub></span> and density <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#961;</i><sub><i>s</i></sub></span>, besides the potential ellipticity, orientation angle, and the centre position (<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#949;</i></span>, <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#952;</i></span>, <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>x</i><sub>0</sub></span>, and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>y</i><sub>0</sub></span>). The main differences between these two models are the presence of a core radius in the PIEMD model, while the PNFW has a central cusp and different slopes at large radii. </p>\n<p>\n            \n            <a name=\"F6\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table><tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/F6.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15-fig6_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/F6.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 4</span></a>\n                <p>MUSE 1D spectra of the multiple images 8a and 8b. The vertical lines indicate the CIII] doublet emission wavelengths of a source at redshift 1.837. The small panels show the circles with <span class=\"simple-math\">1&#8243;</span> (<i>top</i>) and <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15-eq302.png\"></span> (<i>bottom</i>) radius used to extract the two spectra. The flux is rescaled by a factor of <span class=\"simple-math\">10<sup>-18</sup> erg / s / cm<sup>2</sup>/&#197;</span>.</p>\n              </td>\n</tr></table></div>\n          </p>\n<p>\n            \n            <a name=\"F7\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table><tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/F7.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15-fig7_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/F7.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 5</span></a>\n                <p>MUSE 1D spectra of the multiple images 20a and 20b. The vertical line indicates the Ly<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#945;</i></span> emission wavelength of a source at redshift 3.118. The <i>small panels </i>show the circles with <span class=\"simple-math\">1&#8243;</span> radius used to extract the two spectra. The flux is rescaled by a factor of <span class=\"simple-math\">10<sup>-18</sup> erg / s / cm<sup>2</sup>/&#197;</span>.</p>\n              </td>\n</tr></table></div>\n          </p>\n<p>\n            <a name=\"T4\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><div class=\"ligne\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/T4.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Table 4</span></a>\n                <p>Summary of the best-fit models.</p>\n              </div></div>\n          </p>\n<h4 class=\"sec3\">\n<a name=\"S8\"></a>3.1.2. Cluster members and BCG</h4>\n<p>Membership selection is performed following the method adopted in <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R23\">Grillo et al. (2015b, see Sect. 3.3.1)</a>. Specifically, we investigate the loci, in a multi-dimensional colour space, of a large sample of spectroscopically confirmed cluster members and field galaxies. We define confirmed cluster members as the galaxies within the spectroscopic range of <span class=\"simple-math\">0.348 &#177; 0.0135</span>, corresponding to a velocity range of <span class=\"simple-math\">&#177;</span>3000 km&#8201;s<span class=\"simple-math\"><sup>-1</sup></span> in the cluster rest frame. We thus find 145 members out of the 254 galaxies with measured redshifts in the HST field of view. We then model the probability density distributions (PDFs) of cluster member and field galaxy colours as multi-dimensional Gaussians, with means and covariances determined using a robust method (minimum covariance determinant; <a name=\"InR59\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R59\">Rousseeuw 1984</a>). This ensures that a small fraction of outliers in colour space (for example, caused by inaccurate photometry, contamination from angularly close objects, or the presence of star-forming regions) does not significantly perturb the measured properties of the PDFs. The colour distribution is traced by all independent combinations of available bands from the 16 CLASH filters with the exclusion of <i>F225W, F275W, F336W, </i>and <i>F390W </i>bands, which often do not have adequate signal-to-noise ratio for red cluster galaxies. For all galaxies, we compute the probability of being a cluster member or a field galaxy, via the determined PDFs in a Bayesian hypotheses inference. We then classify galaxies with a probability threshold that is a good compromise between purity and completeness, and thus select 159 additional cluster members with no spectroscopic redshifts. </p>\n<p>In the strong lensing model, we consider only (spectroscopic and photometric) cluster members that are within <span class=\"simple-math\">1&#8242;</span> radius from the BCG centre, which encloses all the identified multiple images. In this way, we save computational time by not computing the deflection angle of members in the outer regions of the cluster that are not expected to affect the position of the multiple images significantly. Thus, we include 139 cluster members in the model, 64 of which are spectroscopically confirmed. </p>\n<p>Each cluster member is modelled as dual pseudo-isothermal elliptical mass distribution (dPIE; <a name=\"InR13\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R13\">El&#237;asd&#243;ttir et al. 2007</a>; <a name=\"InR64\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R64\">Suyu &amp; Halkola 2010</a>) with zero ellipticity and core radius, and a finite truncation radius <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>r</i><sub>cut</sub></span>. The projected mass density distribution of this model is given by <a name=\"FD2\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15-eq319.png\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(2)</span></span>Following a standard procedure in cluster-scale strong lensing analyses (e.g. <a name=\"InR26\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R26\">Halkola et al. 2006</a>; <a name=\"InR30\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R30\">Jullo et al. 2007</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R23\">Grillo et al. 2015b</a>), to reduce the number of free parameters describing the cluster members, we use the following relations for the velocity dispersion and truncation radius scaling with the luminosity: <a name=\"FD3\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15-eq320.png\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(3)</span></span>where <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>L</i><sub>0</sub></span> is a reference luminosity associated with the second most luminous cluster member, which is indicated by the magenta circle in Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#F2\">2</a>. Given the adopted relations, the total mass-to-light ratio of the cluster members is constant and we reduce the free parameters of all member galaxies to only two parameters: the reference velocity dispersion <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15-eq322.png\"></span> and truncation radius <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15-eq323.png\"></span>. We measure the luminosities (<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>L</i><sub><i>i</i></sub></span>) in the <i>F160W</i> band, which is the reddest available filter, to minimize the contamination by blue galaxies around cluster members and to obtain a good estimate of galaxy stellar masses. </p>\n<p>Owing to a generally different formation history, the BCG is often observed to deviate significantly from these scaling relations (<a name=\"InR55\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R55\">Postman et al. 2012b</a>). We therefore introduce two additional free parameters associated with the BCG (<span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15-eq325.png\"></span> and <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15-eq326.png\"></span>), keeping its position fixed at the centre of the light distribution. </p>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S9\"></a>3.2. Lens modelling definitions</h3>\n<p>The strong lensing modelling is performed using the public software <i>lenstool </i>(<a name=\"InR36\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R36\">Kneib et al. 1996</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R30\">Jullo et al. 2007</a>).
