The ellipticity <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#949;</i></span> is defined as <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#949;</i> &#8801; 1&#8722;<i>b</i>/<i>a</i></span>, where <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>a</i></span> and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>b</i></span> are the semi-major and minor axis, respectively. There are six parameters describing this model: the centre position (<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>x</i><sub>0</sub></span> and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>y</i><sub>0</sub></span>), the ellipticity and its orientation angle (<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#949;</i></span> and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#952;</i></span>, where the horizontal is the principal axis and the angle is counted counterclockwise), the fiducial velocity dispersion (<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#963;</i><sub>v</sub></span>), and the core radius (<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>r</i><sub>core</sub></span>). The PIEMD parametrization has been shown to be a good model to describe cluster mass distributions in strong lensing studies and sometimes provides a better fit than the canonical Navarro-Frenk-White (hereafter NFW; <a name=\"InR48\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R48\">Navarro et al. 1996</a>, <a name=\"InR49\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R49\">1997</a>) mass distribution. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R23\">Grillo et al. (2015b)</a>, using a similar high quality data set, found for example that the dark matter components of the HFF galaxy cluster MACS J0416.1<span class=\"simple-math\">&#8722;</span>2403 are better described by PIEMD models. </p>\n<p>To test the dependence of our main results on a specific mass parametrization, we also consider an NFW distribution for the main dark matter component. In this work, we use a NFW model with elliptical potential (hereafther PNFW; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R33\">Kassiola &amp; Kovner 1993</a>; <a name=\"InR35\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R35\">Kneib 2002</a>; <a name=\"InR18\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R18\">Golse &amp; Kneib 2002</a>), which significantly reduces computing time of the deflection angle across the image in the <i>lenstool </i>implementation. For this model, the free parameters are the characteristic radius <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>r</i><sub><i>s</i></sub></span> and density <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#961;</i><sub><i>s</i></sub></span>, besides the potential ellipticity, orientation angle, and the centre position (<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#949;</i></span>, <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#952;</i></span>, <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>x</i><sub>0</sub></span>, and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>y</i><sub>0</sub></span>). The main differences between these two models are the presence of a core radius in the PIEMD model, while the PNFW has a central cusp and different slopes at large radii. </p>\n<p>\n            \n            <a name=\"F6\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table><tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/F6.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15-fig6_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/F6.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 4</span></a>\n                <p>MUSE 1D spectra of the multiple images 8a and 8b. The vertical lines indicate the CIII] doublet emission wavelengths of a source at redshift 1.837. The small panels show the circles with <span class=\"simple-math\">1&#8243;</span> (<i>top</i>) and <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15-eq302.png\"></span> (<i>bottom</i>) radius used to extract the two spectra. The flux is rescaled by a factor of <span class=\"simple-math\">10<sup>-18</sup> erg / s / cm<sup>2</sup>/&#197;</span>.</p>\n              </td>\n</tr></table></div>\n          </p>\n<p>\n            \n            <a name=\"F7\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table><tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/F7.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15-fig7_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/F7.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 5</span></a>\n                <p>MUSE 1D spectra of the multiple images 20a and 20b. The vertical line indicates the Ly<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#945;</i></span> emission wavelength of a source at redshift 3.118. The <i>small panels </i>show the circles with <span class=\"simple-math\">1&#8243;</span> radius used to extract the two spectra. The flux is rescaled by a factor of <span class=\"simple-math\">10<sup>-18</sup> erg / s / cm<sup>2</sup>/&#197;</span>.</p>\n              </td>\n</tr></table></div>\n          </p>\n<p>\n            <a name=\"T4\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><div class=\"ligne\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/T4.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Table 4</span></a>\n                <p>Summary of the best-fit models.</p>\n              </div></div>\n          </p>\n<h4 class=\"sec3\">\n<a name=\"S8\"></a>3.1.2. Cluster members and BCG</h4>\n<p>Membership selection is performed following the method adopted in <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R23\">Grillo et al. (2015b, see Sect. 3.3.1)</a>. Specifically, we investigate the loci, in a multi-dimensional colour space, of a large sample of spectroscopically confirmed cluster members and field galaxies. We define confirmed cluster members as the galaxies within the spectroscopic range of <span class=\"simple-math\">0.348 &#177; 0.0135</span>, corresponding to a velocity range of <span class=\"simple-math\">&#177;</span>3000 km&#8201;s<span class=\"simple-math\"><sup>-1</sup></span> in the cluster rest frame. We thus find 145 members out of the 254 galaxies with measured redshifts in the HST field of view. We then model the probability density distributions (PDFs) of cluster member and field galaxy colours as multi-dimensional Gaussians, with means and covariances determined using a robust method (minimum covariance determinant; <a name=\"InR59\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R59\">Rousseeuw 1984</a>). This ensures that a small fraction of outliers in colour space (for example, caused by inaccurate photometry, contamination from angularly close objects, or the presence of star-forming regions) does not significantly perturb the measured properties of the PDFs. The colour distribution is traced by all independent combinations of available bands from the 16 CLASH filters with the exclusion of <i>F225W, F275W, F336W, </i>and <i>F390W </i>bands, which often do not have adequate signal-to-noise ratio for red cluster galaxies. For all galaxies, we compute the probability of being a cluster member or a field galaxy, via the determined PDFs in a Bayesian hypotheses inference. We then classify galaxies with a probability threshold that is a good compromise between purity and completeness, and thus select 159 additional cluster members with no spectroscopic redshifts. </p>\n<p>In the strong lensing model, we consider only (spectroscopic and photometric) cluster members that are within <span class=\"simple-math\">1&#8242;</span> radius from the BCG centre, which encloses all the identified multiple images. In this way, we save computational time by not computing the deflection angle of members in the outer regions of the cluster that are not expected to affect the position of the multiple images significantly. Thus, we include 139 cluster members in the model, 64 of which are spectroscopically confirmed. </p>\n<p>Each cluster member is modelled as dual pseudo-isothermal elliptical mass distribution (dPIE; <a name=\"InR13\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R13\">El&#237;asd&#243;ttir et al. 2007</a>; <a name=\"InR64\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R64\">Suyu &amp; Halkola 2010</a>) with zero ellipticity and core radius, and a finite truncation radius <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>r</i><sub>cut</sub></span>. The projected mass density distribution of this model is given by <a name=\"FD2\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15-eq319.png\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(2)</span></span>Following a standard procedure in cluster-scale strong lensing analyses (e.g. <a name=\"InR26\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R26\">Halkola et al. 2006</a>; <a name=\"InR30\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R30\">Jullo et al. 2007</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R23\">Grillo et al. 2015b</a>), to reduce the number of free parameters describing the cluster members, we use the following relations for the velocity dispersion and truncation radius scaling with the luminosity: <a name=\"FD3\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15-eq320.png\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(3)</span></span>where <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>L</i><sub>0</sub></span> is a reference luminosity associated with the second most luminous cluster member, which is indicated by the magenta circle in Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#F2\">2</a>. Given the adopted relations, the total mass-to-light ratio of the cluster members is constant and we reduce the free parameters of all member galaxies to only two parameters: the reference velocity dispersion <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15-eq322.png\"></span> and truncation radius <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15-eq323.png\"></span>. We measure the luminosities (<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>L</i><sub><i>i</i></sub></span>) in the <i>F160W</i> band, which is the reddest available filter, to minimize the contamination by blue galaxies around cluster members and to obtain a good estimate of galaxy stellar masses. </p>\n<p>Owing to a generally different formation history, the BCG is often observed to deviate significantly from these scaling relations (<a name=\"InR55\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R55\">Postman et al. 2012b</a>). We therefore introduce two additional free parameters associated with the BCG (<span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15-eq325.png\"></span> and <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15-eq326.png\"></span>), keeping its position fixed at the centre of the light distribution. </p>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S9\"></a>3.2. Lens modelling definitions</h3>\n<p>The strong lensing modelling is performed using the public software <i>lenstool </i>(<a name=\"InR36\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R36\">Kneib et al. 1996</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R30\">Jullo et al. 2007</a>). Once the model mass components are defined, the best-fitting model parameters are found by minimizing the distance between the observed and model-predicted positions of the multiple images, and the parameter covariance is quantified with a Bayesian Markov chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) technique. </p>\n<p>In detail, to find the best-fitting model, we define the lens plane <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#967;</i><sup>2</sup></span> function as follows: <a name=\"FD4\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15-eq328.png\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(4)</span></span>where <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>N</i><sub>fam</sub></span> and <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15-eq330.png\"></span> are the number of families and number of multiple images belonging to the family <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>j</i></span>, respectively. The parameters <span class=\"simple-math\"><b><i>&#952;</i></b><sup>obs</sup></span> and <span class=\"simple-math\"><b><i>&#952;</i></b><sup>pred</sup></span> are the observed and model-predicted positions of the multiple images, and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#963;</i><sup>obs</sup></span> is the uncertainty in the observed position. The model-predicted position of an image is a function of the both lens parameters and cosmological parameters, which are all represented by the vector <span class=\"simple-math\"><b>&#928;</b></span>. We adopt flat priors on all parameters, thus, the set of parameters <span class=\"simple-math\"><b>&#928;</b></span> that provides the minimum value of the <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#967;</i><sup>2</sup></span> function (<span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15-eq314.png\"></span>) is called the best-fitting model, while the predicted positions of this model are referred to as <span class=\"simple-math\"><b><i>&#952;</i></b><sup>bf</sup></span>. We do not have measured spectroscopic redshifts for some multiple image families. In these cases, the family redshift is also a free parameter optimized in the calculation of the <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15-eq314.png\"></span> with a flat prior. </p>\n<p>Aside from the value of the <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15-eq314.png\"></span>, we can quantify the goodness of the fit with the root-mean-square between the observed and reconstructed positions of the multiple images: <a name=\"FD5\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15-eq337.png\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(5)</span></span>where <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>N</i></span> is the total number of multiple images. This quantity does not depend on the value of the observed uncertainties <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#963;</i><sup>obs</sup></span>, making it suitable when comparing results of different works. Finally, we also define the displacement of a single multiple image <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>i</i></span> as <a name=\"FD6\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15-eq340.png\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(6)</span></span>The posterior probability distribution function of the free parameters is given by the product of the likelihood function and the prior <a name=\"FD7\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15-eq341.png\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(7)</span></span>where P(<span class=\"simple-math\"><b>&#928;</b></span>) is the prior, which we consider to be flat for all free parameters. We use a MCMC with at least <span class=\"simple-math\">10<sup>5</sup></span> points and a convergence speed rate of 0.1 (a parameter of the <i>BayeSys</i><sup><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#FN11\">2</a></sup> algorithm used by the <i>lenstool </i>software) to properly sample the parameter space and obtain the posterior distribution of the parameter values. We have checked that these values ensure the convergence of the chains. All computations are performed estimating the value of the <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#967;</i><sup>2</sup></span> function on the image plane, which is formally more accurate than working on the source plane (e.g. <a name=\"InR34\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R34\">Keeton 2001</a>). </p>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S10\"></a>3.3. Cosmological parameters</h3>\n<p>The availability of a large number of multiple images, with spectroscopic redshifts spanning a wide range, in a relatively regular mass distribution, makes RXC J2248 a suitable cluster lens to test the possibility of constraining cosmological parameters. Strong lensing is sensitive to the underlying geometry of the Universe via the angular diameter distances from the observer to the lens (<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>D</i><sub>OL</sub></span>) and source (<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>D</i><sub>OS</sub></span>), and from the lens to the source (<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>D</i><sub>LS</sub></span>). For one source, the lens equation can be written as <a name=\"FD8\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15-eq346.png\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(8)</span></span>where <span class=\"simple-math\"><b><i>&#952;</i></b></span> and <span class=\"simple-math\"><b><i>&#946;</i></b></span> are the angular positions on the lens and source planes, respectively, <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15-eq349.png\"></span> is the deflection angle and the cosmological dependence is embedded into the angular diameter distances. In general, the ratio between the cosmological distances can be absorbed by the parameters of the lens mass distribution (i.e. the factor that multiplies the mass distribution), which is <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15-eq350.png\"></span> in the PIEMD case. However, when a significant number of multiply lensed sources at different redshifts is present, this degeneracy can be broken and a leverage on cosmological parameters can be obtained via the so-called family ratio: <a name=\"FD9\"></a><span class=\"img-equation\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15-eq351.png\"><span class=\"label-eq\">(9)</span></span>where <span class=\"simple-math\"><b><i>&#960;</i></b></span> is the set of cosmological parameters and 1 and 2 are two different sources at redshifts <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i><sub>s1</sub></span> and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i><sub>s2</sub></span>. This technique has been applied in <a name=\"InR62\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R62\">Soucail et al. (2004)</a> and <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R31\">Jullo et al. (2010)</a> for the galaxy clusters Abell 2218 and Abell 1689, respectively. We use the <span class=\"simple-math\">&#923;</span>CDM cosmological model, which includes as free parameters the energy density of the total matter of the Universe (ordinary and dark matter) <span class=\"simple-math\">&#937;<sub>m</sub></span>, the dark energy density <span class=\"simple-math\">&#937;<sub>&#923;</sub></span> and the equation of state parameter of this last component, <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>w</i> = <i>P</i>/<i>&#961;</i></span>. All the results from our lens models are described in Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#S12\">4</a>. </p>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S11\"></a>3.4. Multiple image selection</h3>\n<p>In the previous strong lensing studies of RXC J2248, 19 candidates of multiple image families were identified (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R46\">Monna et al. 2014</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R28\">Johnson et al. 2014</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R56\">Richard et al. 2014</a>), however, some of them are not secure candidates. The selection of secure multiple image systems, i.e. systems with spectroscopic confirmation or multiple images with correct parity and/or consistent colours, is essential to avoid systematics in lensing models. This criterion leaves us with 16 families, whose properties are summarized in Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#T1\">1</a>. Based on this strict criterion, we do not include the counter image 16c in our models, since the corresponding model-predicted position from our best-fitting models (see Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#S12\">4</a>) is close to two objects with similar colours, leaving the identification of this counter image uncertain. </p>\n<p>Given our relatively simple models to parametrize the cluster mass distribution and the total mass-luminosity scaling relation of the cluster members, we also avoid multiple images in the vicinity of the members. Their truncated PIEMD mass with a constant total mass-to-light ratio might not be able to accurately reproduce the positions of the multiple images close to the core of the members, introducing a bias in the best fits. Quantitatively, we do not include multiple images closer than <span class=\"simple-math\">3 kpc</span> (<span class=\"simple-math\">&#8776;</span><span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15-eq357.png\"></span>) to a cluster member, which is approximately the Einstein&#8217;s radius of a galaxy with <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#963;</i><sub>v</sub> = 160</span> km&#8201;s<span class=\"simple-math\"><sup>-1</sup></span> for a source at <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> = 3</span>. As a result, the multiple images that are not included in our fiducial lens model are 3b, 8a, 8b, and 17b. In the case of family 8, we are left with only one multiple image, which does add any constraint to the models; we therefore exclude the entire family. </p>\n<p>Finally, in all different models we analyze, family 11 presents a much larger offset between observed and reconstructed images (<span class=\"simple-math\">&#916;<sub><i>i</i></sub> &#8776; 1&#8243;</span>) when compared with the other families (<span class=\"simple-math\">&#8776;</span><span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15-eq7.png\"></span>). We conduct several tests in the effort to improve the fit of this family: 1) we freely vary the mass parameter of the nearby cluster members when optimizing the model. 2) We introduce a dark halo in the vicinity of the images. 3) We consider an external shear component represented by a PIEMD in the south-west region of the cluster with free mass. The third test is suggested by the apparent discontinuity in the X-ray emission from the <i>Chandra </i>data, <span class=\"simple-math\">~</span>30<span class=\"simple-math\">&#8243;</span> SW of the BCG. We verify that it is difficult to reduce the average value of <span class=\"simple-math\">&#916;<sub><i>i</i></sub></span> below <span class=\"simple-math\">1&#8243;</span> for the images of family 11 by only adding an extra mass component. </p>\n<p>We also consider the effect of the large-scale structure along the line of sight, which we can sample with our redshift survey. Specifically, to investigate whether this family could be lensed by a galaxy behind the cluster, we map the positions of the three multiple images onto a plane at the redshift of each background source in the Tables <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#T1\">1</a> and <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#T3\">3</a>. In this analysis, we find that the background galaxy ID B7 at <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> = 1.270</span> (see Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#T3\">3</a>) could significantly perturb the positions of the multiple images of family 11, since its distance is <span class=\"simple-math\">&#8776;</span>25<span class=\"simple-math\"> kpc</span>, or <span class=\"simple-math\">&#8776;</span>3<span class=\"simple-math\">&#8243;</span>, from the positions of the multiple images 11a and 11b on the <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> = 1.27</span> plane. In this configuration, assuming a velocity dispersion value of 150 km&#8201;s<span class=\"simple-math\"><sup>-1</sup></span> for B7, the deflection angle induced in the multiple images of family 11 is <span class=\"simple-math\">&#8776;</span><span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15-eq366.png\"></span>. We therefore argue that the effect of this background galaxy can partially explain the large <span class=\"simple-math\">&#916;<sub><i>i</i></sub></span> value of this family, although more complex multi-plane ray-tracing procedures should be employed to fully account for such a deviation. A detailed modelling of the background effects on the strong lensing analyses of RXC J2248 is out of the scope of this work. However, in Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#S16\">5</a> we return to this non-negligible issue by estimating the statistical effect on the image positions due to the line-of-sight mass structure, and we show that it can have an important impact on high-precision lensing modelling. </p>\n<p>To summarize, in an effort to minimize possible sources of systematic uncertainties, we decide not to include the multiple images 3b, 16c and 17b, and families 8 and 11 in our strong lensing analysis. In the end, we consider a total of 38 multiple images of which 19 are spectroscopically confirmed, belonging to 14 families at different redshifts. We leave the detailed study of individual sources to future work. As the spectroscopic work continues, particularly with VLT/MUSE, we will include a further refinement of the mass distribution modelling, which will take the influence of mass strictures along the line of sight into account. </p>\n<h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"S12\"></a>4. Results</h2>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S13\"></a>4.1. A collection of lens models</h3>\n<p>We explore a number of strong lensing models based on different samples of secure multiple-image systems, as described above, and different model parameters. </p>\n<p>First we define two samples of multiple-image families: &#8220;family sample 1&#8221; includes families with spectroscopic confirmation, namely families with IDs 2, 3, 4, 6, 7, 14, and 18, totalling 20 multiple images in seven families; &#8220;family sample 2&#8221; contains all the secure families, including also multiple images with no spectroscopic confirmation, but with correct colours and parity as expected from gravitational lensing theory. This extended sample includes family IDs 9, 13, 15, 16, 17, 20, and 21 in addition to the seven spectroscopic families, totalling 38 multiple images in 14 families. The redshift of the compact multiple images of family 20 is conservatively considered a free parameter here, since the multiple images are not necessarily associated with the extended Ly<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#945;</i></span> emission (see Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#S4\">2.2</a>). We find, however, that the best-fit redshift of family 20 obtained from the strong lensing model is in very good agreement with that derived from the LAB emission, confirming a posteriori that the compact sources of family 20 are associated with the extended Ly<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#945;</i></span> emission (see Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#F7\">5</a>). Since this extra information does not improve the lens models significantly, we did not recompute the MCMC analyses for all the reference models. </p>\n<p>To optimize the models, we adopt an image positional error of <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15-eq60.png\"></span> in the positions of the multiple images, which is in agreement with predictions of the effects of matter density fluctuations along the line of sight on the positions of multiple images (<a name=\"InR27\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R27\">Host 2012</a>). In all cases this choice leads to a <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15-eq367.png\"></span> lower than the number of degrees of freedom (<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>d</i><i>.</i><i>o</i><i>.</i><i>f</i><i>.</i></span>; defined as the difference between the number of constraints and the number of free parameters of a model). Positional errors (<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#963;</i><sup>obs</sup></span> in Eq. (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#FD4\">4</a>)) are then rescaled to yield a <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15-eq314.png\"></span> value equal to the <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>d</i><i>.</i><i>o</i><i>.</i><i>f</i><i>.</i></span> when probing the space parameter using the MCMC technique. The values of the rescaled <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#963;</i><sup>obs</sup></span> are approximately <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15-eq368.png\"></span> for all the models under study. This can effectively account for, e.g. line-of-sight mass structures and the scatter in the adopted total mass-to-light relation of the cluster members. </p>\n<p>We exploit different lensing models to assess possible systematic effects stemming from our assumptions on the cluster total mass distribution, multiple image systems and adopted free parameters. A list of all models is given in Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#T4\">4</a>, including their main parameters and a brief description of each model. </p>\n<p>The IDs of the models are composed of letters indicating the model assumption. The letter &#8220;F&#8221; indicates a fixed cosmology (flat <span class=\"simple-math\">&#923;CDM</span> cosmology with <span class=\"simple-math\">&#937;<sub>m</sub> = 0.3</span> and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>H</i><sub>0</sub> = 70</span> km&#8201;s<span class=\"simple-math\"><sup>-1</sup></span>&#8201;Mpc<span class=\"simple-math\"><sup>-1</sup></span>), and &#8220;N&#8221; indicates that we use a PNFW mass profile to represent the smooth dark matter mass distribution instead of a PIEMD. The letter &#8220;W&#8221; indicates that we vary the parameters <span class=\"simple-math\">&#937;<sub>m</sub></span> and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>w</i></span> (the dark energy equation of state, in a flat Universe) while &#8220;L&#8221; indicates free <span class=\"simple-math\">&#937;<sub>m</sub></span> and <span class=\"simple-math\">&#937;<sub>&#923;</sub></span> and fixed <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>w</i> = &#8722;1</span> (i.e. we vary the curvature of the Universe). The letters &#8220;WL&#8221; indicate we are varying all the three cosmological parameters at the same time. Finally, the ID &#8220;Wa&#8221; stands for a model where we consider a variation of <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>w</i></span> with redshift parametrized by <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>w</i>(<i>z</i>) = <i>w</i><sub>0</sub> + <i>w</i><sub><i>a</i></sub><i>z</i>/ (1 + <i>z</i>)</span>. </p>\n<p>The numbers in the IDs indicate three different multiple image inputs. The number &#8220;1&#8221; indicates that we consider only the family sample 1, while &#8220;2&#8221; refers to all the secure families (family sample 2). Moreover, for two models we also explore the effect of removing the highest redshift source (family 14) on the best-fitting parameters (indicated by &#8220;3&#8221;). The letter &#8220;Z&#8221; indicates the models in which we do not use any information on the spectroscopic redshifts, i.e. the redshifts of all families are free parameters in the optimization. For completeness, we also quote results for the model F1a, in which all spectroscopic families are included, i.e. the model F1 with the addition of the families 11 and 8, and image 3b. Although the model F1a has a poor overall fit due to the systematics introduced by the non-bona fide multiple images, it is more accurate to compute lensing quantities, such as the magnification, of these specific multiple images. Finally, after the identification of the fifth image, belonging to family 14 and close to the BCG, we include this image into an additional model. The model F1-5th considers the family sample 1 plus this extra image. We therefore present best-fit models for 22 different cases. </p>\n<p>For a subset of models in Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#T4\">4</a>, we compute parameter uncertainties by performing a MCMC analysis. Since this can be very time consuming, we do not consider models N1, N2, NW1, and NW2 because they do not accurately describe the properties of the lens mass distribution (see Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#S14\">4.2</a>). We also exclude the models Wa1 and Wa2 because we find that the multiple image positions are not very sensitive to the variation of the <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>w</i><sub><i>a</i></sub></span> parameter. In Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#T5\">5</a>, we show the best-fit parameters and their errors (68% confidence level) for the 12 models for which the MCMC analysis was performed (the model IDs refer to Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#T4\">4</a>). We do not show the estimated redshift of the family sample 1 for better visualisation for the models FZ1 and FZ2. In the next sections, we discuss the results from the best-fit models on the mass distribution of RXC J2248, the cosmological parameters, and the degree of degeneracy among the different model parameters. </p>\n<p>\n          <a name=\"T5\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><div class=\"ligne\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/T5.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Table 5</span></a>\n              <p>Results of the MCMC statistical analysis for the strong lensing models of Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#T4\">4</a>.</p>\n            </div></div>\n        </p>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S14\"></a>4.2. Mass distribution parameters</h3>\n<p>Firstly, the PNFW models provide a significantly worse fit than the PIEMD models (compare models F1 and F2 with N1 and N2 in Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#T4\">4</a>). The final positional <span class=\"simple-math\">&#916;<sub>rms</sub></span> of N1 and N2 is a factor of 3.5 and 3.9 higher than that of F1 and F2, respectively. The main reason for this difference is that RXC J2248 is characterized by a relatively shallow inner mass density distribution, as pointed out by previous works (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R28\">Johnson et al. 2014</a>; <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R46\">Monna et al. 2014</a>). Moreover, when we let the values of the cosmological parameters (<span class=\"simple-math\">&#937;<sub>m</sub></span> and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>w</i></span>) to vary in the model optimization, the <span class=\"simple-math\">&#916;<sub>rms</sub></span> is reduced by a factor of 2 for the NW1 and NW2 models. This indicates that a different set of cosmological parameters partially compensates the effects of the presence of a core in the total mass density profile of the cluster. Specifically, we obtain best-fit cosmological parameters <span class=\"simple-math\">&#937;<sub>m</sub> &#8776; 0.0</span> and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>w</i> &lt; &#8722;2.0</span>, which are completely non-physical and in disagreement with other cosmological probes. Moreover, the large <span class=\"simple-math\">&#916;<sub>rms</sub></span> value in this case indicates that this mass distribution profile is such a bad representation of the real profile that the lensing models are unable to probe parameters related to the background cosmology and halo substructures. </p>\n<p>By comparing the models with fixed cosmology using the redshift information of the family sample 1, i.e. models F1 and F2 in the Tables <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#T4\">4</a> and <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#T5\">5</a>, we find that the extra information of the family sample 2 does not significantly change the strong lens modelling. This is indicated by the fact that the <span class=\"simple-math\">&#916;<sub>rms</sub></span> values of these two models are very similar (see Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#T4\">4</a>) and the values of all parameters are also consistent within their <span class=\"simple-math\">1<i>&#963;</i></span> confidence levels in Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#T5\">5</a>. A larger deviation is obtained for the BCG parameters <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15-eq325.png\"></span> and <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15-eq326.png\"></span>, which are not estimated very precisely because the degeneracies with the other parameters and lack of multiple images close to the BCG. This behaviour is present in all the 12 different models we analyzed. We remark that the inclusion of image 14e allows us to obtain a more precise estimate of the value of the effective velocity dispersion of the BCG, but not of its truncation radius. In detail, we find that the median values and 68% confidence levels for these two parameters from the model F1-5th are <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15-eq668.png\"></span><span class=\"simple-math\">km s<sup>-1</sup></span> and <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15-eq670.png\"></span><span class=\"simple-math\">&#8243;</span>. </p>\n<p>Interestingly, the addition of extra families of the sample 2 allows us to reduce the errors on the best-fitting parameters and to place significant constraints on the redshifts of these extra multiple image families. We consider the model F2 as our reference model, since we use the maximum possible and secure information of the clean sample of multiple images. In Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#F8\">6</a>, we show <span class=\"simple-math\">4&#8243;</span> wide cutouts of the multiple images used in this model. The red circles have <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15-eq60.png\"></span> radius and locate the observed input positions listed in Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#T1\">1</a>. The yellow crosses are the predicted positions of the lens model F2. All multiple images are very well reproduced by the model and there is no systematic offset in the predicted positions. </p>\n<p>\n          <a name=\"F8\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table><tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/F8.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15-fig8_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/F8.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 6</span></a>\n              <p>CLASH/HST colour cutouts (<span class=\"simple-math\">4&#8243;</span> wide) of all multiple images used in the reference model F2. Red circles (<span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15-eq60.png\"></span> radius) indicate the observed positions while the yellow crosses the model-predicted positions. The multiple image ID 14e is shown in the HFF cutout and the best-fitting position (blue cross) is given by the model F1-5th.</p>\n            </td>\n</tr></table></div>\n        </p>\n<p>\n          <a name=\"F9\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table><tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/F9.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15-fig9_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/F9.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 6</span></a>\n              <p>continued.</p>\n            </td>\n</tr></table></div>\n        </p>\n<p>\n          <a name=\"F10\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table><tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/F10.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15-fig10_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/F10.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 7</span></a>\n              <p>Distribution of the displacement values of the multiple images (absolute values of the observed minus the reconstructed positions, see Eq. (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#FD6\">6</a>)) obtained from our reference model F2 (solid blue line) and in previous works by <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R46\">Monna et al.</a> (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R46\">2014</a>; green dashed) and <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R28\">Johnson et al.</a> (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R28\">2014</a>; red long dashed), for the cluster RXC J2248.</p>\n            </td>\n</tr></table></div>\n        </p>\n<p>In Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#F10\">7</a>, we compare the distribution of the displacements of each multiple image (<span class=\"simple-math\">&#916;<sub><i>i</i></sub></span>, see Eq. (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#FD6\">6</a>)) of the reference model F2 with those relative to the multiple images considered in <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R46\">Monna et al. (2014)</a> and <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R28\">Johnson et al. (2014)</a> (the only studies that made this information available). This figure shows that our model reproduces the multiple image positions with better accuracy compared to previous works. Specifically, the final <span class=\"simple-math\">&#916;<sub>rms</sub></span> (Eq. (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#FD5\">5</a>)) of our model is <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15-eq672.png\"></span>, while is <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15-eq673.png\"></span> in <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R46\">Monna et al. (2014)</a> and <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15-eq674.png\"></span> in <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R28\">Johnson et al. (2014)</a>. This difference can be explained by different assumptions in each modelling, such as extra dark matter halos and different cluster member selections, slightly distinct multiple image families, and different redshift information. </p>\n<p>We can compare the projected total mass values within an aperture of <span class=\"simple-math\">250 kpc</span> from these studies. Using the <span class=\"simple-math\">1<i>&#963;</i></span> confidence level of our F2 model, we find <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15-eq676.png\"></span> (the errors are given by the 68% confidence level), which is somewhat higher than the values of <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15-eq677.png\"></span> and <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15-eq678.png\"></span> presented in <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R28\">Johnson et al. (2014)</a> and <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R46\">Monna et al. (2014)</a>, respectively. Although these measurements are not consistent within the estimated errors, the mean values do not differ more than 10%, and are likely due to different assumptions in these studies, and aforementiond systematics arising from a non-bona fide set of multiple images. </p>\n<p>Since strong lensing modelling in galaxy clusters is often not supported by extensive spectroscopy of lensed background sources, we examine the impact of not using spectroscopic information in the lens modelling. We initially compute the best-fit model assuming all families&#8217;s redshifts as free parameters for a fixed cosmology (models FZ1 and FZ2) and varying <span class=\"simple-math\">&#937;<sub>m</sub></span> and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>w</i></span> (models WZ1 and WZ2, see Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#T4\">4</a>). Comparing models F1 and F2 with FZ1 and FZ2, we see the value of <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#963;</i><sub>v</sub></span> decreases by <span class=\"simple-math\">&#8776;</span>3<span class=\"simple-math\">%</span> for models F1 and FZ1, and <span class=\"simple-math\">&#8776;</span>2<span class=\"simple-math\">%</span> for F2 and FZ2. Even within the <span class=\"simple-math\">1<i>&#963;</i></span> confidence level, this difference is more likely to be caused by systematics introduced by the missing redshift information than by statistical fluctuations. </p>\n<p>\n          <a name=\"F11\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table><tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/F11.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15-fig11_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/F11.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 8</span></a>\n              <p>Best-fit redshift values of the multiple image families compared with the spectroscopic, in blue, and photometric, in green, redshift values. The arrows indicate the unconstrained redshifts and the black line the relation <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i><sub>spec,phot</sub> = <i>z</i><sub>best fit</sub></span>. We use the spectroscopic redshift value measured from the Ly<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#945;</i></span> blob for family 20.</p>\n            </td>\n</tr></table></div>\n        </p>\n<p>There is a well-known degeneracy between the mass of a lens (parametrised by <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#963;</i><sub>v</sub></span>) and the distance of a lensed source. Simplifying, as the source distance increases the lens mass has to decrease to match the same multiple image positions. From Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#T4\">4</a>, the best-fitting redshift values of the model FZ2 are all systematically larger than those of the model F2. In Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#F11\">8</a>, we compare the model-predicted redshifts (<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i><sub>best fit</sub></span>) of all the 14 multiple image families with the spectroscopic (blue marks) and photometric (green) estimates from <a name=\"InR29\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R29\">Jouvel et al. (2014)</a>, with <span class=\"simple-math\">95%</span> confidence level error bars. We choose the multiple image with the highest value of the <i>odds </i>parameter from the photo-<i>z</i> algorithm (see Sect. 3.3 of  <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R29\">Jouvel et al. 2014</a>) to associate only one photometric redshift value with each family. As expected, for the low-redshift families (<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i><sub>spec,phot</sub>&lt; 2</span>) the agreement between the model predictions and the measurements is very good. However, for families at higher redshifts the difference increases significantly and progressively, always leading to overestimate the redshift value. For families with <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i><sub>spec,phot</sub>&gt; 4</span>, redshifts are basically unconstrained, indicating that spectroscopic measurements for these sources become critical to avoid significant systematic uncertainties on the mass (and cosmological) parameters. </p>\n<p>\n          <a name=\"F12\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table><tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/F12.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15-fig12_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/F12.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 9</span></a>\n              <p>Confidence regions for the redshifts values of the families with no spectroscopic confirmation. Red regions: the redshift values of the spectroscopically confirmed families are fixed. Grey regions: the redshift values of all families are left free. These correspond to models F2 and FZ2, respectively, in Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#T4\">4</a>. The contours represent the <span class=\"simple-math\">68%</span>, <span class=\"simple-math\">95.4%</span>, and <span class=\"simple-math\">99.7%</span> confidence levels.</p>\n            </td>\n</tr></table></div>\n        </p>\n<p>In Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#F12\">9</a>, we show the confidence regions, estimated from the MCMC analysis, of the best-fit redshifts for the model FZ2 (in grey) and F2 (in red). In the model FZ2 (all redshifts left free), the redshift values are all strongly correlated. This effect becomes larger, in absolute values, for the sources at higher redshifts. For the model F2, the confidence regions are much smaller and the correlation is much less pronounced. Moreover, the overlap of the confidence regions for the two models occur only at low redshifts and only in the <span class=\"simple-math\">3<i>&#963;</i></span> area of the model FZ2, again indicating the bias introduced by the lack of spectroscopic information. The absence of information about the source redshifts results in a best-fitting model with a lower total mass for the cluster that is compensated by higher values for the source redshifts. The degeneracy between the total cluster mass and source redshifts explains the difference of <span class=\"simple-math\">&#8776;</span>3<span class=\"simple-math\">%</span> in the value of the effective velocity dispersion (<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#963;</i><sub>v</sub></span>), linked to the total cluster mass, of the models F1, F2 and FZ1, FZ2. For the model FZ2, we find a total mass projected within <span class=\"simple-math\">250 kpc</span> of <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15-eq689.png\"></span>, a difference of approximately 4% when compared with F2. This shows that the measurements of the projected total mass are similar, despite the large redshift bias. On the contrary, since the best-fit redshift values are biased, we expect that quantities that depend directly on cosmological distances, such as <span class=\"simple-math\">&#926;</span> in Eq. (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#FD9\">9</a>), will also be biased if spectroscopic redshifts are not available. </p>\n<p>By leaving the redshift values of all families free, we increase the number of free parameters by 7 and 14 for family sample 1 and 2, respectively. Clearly, the larger number of free parameters reduces the value of the final <span class=\"simple-math\">&#916;<sub>rms</sub></span> (and consequently <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15-eq367.png\"></span>), but biases the recovered parameters, principally the cosmological parameters. For the models WZ1 and WZ2, the best-fit cosmological parameters are <span class=\"simple-math\">&#937;<sub>m</sub> = 1.0</span> and 0.6, and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>w</i> =</span><span class=\"simple-math\">&#8722;1.4</span> and <span class=\"simple-math\">&#8722;1.3</span>, respectively. These values are in disagreement with other established cosmological probes, showing that missing information on the background source redshifts makes cosmological constraints unreliable. In Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#S15\">4.3</a>, however, we show that if one starts with a large sample of spectroscopically confirmed multiple image families, the addition of more secure families with no redshift information does not bias the estimates of the cosmological parameters. </p>\n<h3 class=\"sec2\">\n<a name=\"S15\"></a>4.3. Cosmological parameters</h3>\n<p>We focus here on the ability of the lensing model to constrain the cosmological parameters, by considering three different <span class=\"simple-math\">&#923;CDM</span> models: 1) a flat cosmological model with free <span class=\"simple-math\">&#937;<sub>m</sub></span> and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>w</i></span> (ID W); 2) a cosmological model with fixed <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>w</i> = &#8722;1</span>, but allowing different curvature values, i.e. free <span class=\"simple-math\">&#937;<sub>m</sub></span> and <span class=\"simple-math\">&#937;<sub>&#923;</sub></span> (ID L); and 3) a cosmological model with three parameters free, <span class=\"simple-math\">&#937;<sub>m</sub></span>, <span class=\"simple-math\">&#937;<sub>&#923;</sub></span>, and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>w</i></span>, (ID WL). </p>\n<p>From Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#T4\">4</a>, we find that the models with fixed cosmological parameters, F1 and F2, have larger <span class=\"simple-math\">&#916;<sub>rms</sub></span> values than those allowing some freedom in the background cosmological model, showing the leverage of the cosmological parameters on the multiple image positions. For instance, the reduced <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#967;</i><sup>2</sup></span> (<span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15-eq367.png\"></span>/d.o.f.) decreases by <span class=\"simple-math\">&#8776;</span>13<span class=\"simple-math\">%</span> when we compare the model F1, including the spectroscopic confirmed families with fixed cosmology, with the models W1 and L1, where the value of the cosmological parameters are left free. </p>\n<p>\n          \n          <a name=\"F13\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table><tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/F13.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15-fig13_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/F13.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 10</span></a>\n              <p>Confidence levels (black lines) for the cosmological parameters of models W1 and W2 (<span class=\"simple-math\">&#937;<sub>m</sub> + &#937;<sub>&#923;</sub> = 1</span>, <i>top panels</i>) and L1 and L2 (<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>w</i> = &#8722;1</span>, <i>bottom panels</i>). <i>Left panels </i>refer to strong lensing models using only spectroscopic families (L1, W1); models in the <i>right panels </i>include all families (L2, W2). Red lines: contours from <i>Planck </i>Data Release 2 data. Blue regions: combined constraints. The yellow circles indicate the maximum likelihood peak in this projection.</p>\n            </td>\n</tr></table></div>\n        </p>\n<p>In flat cosmological models, the 68% confidence levels for each parameter yield: <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15-eq696.png\"></span>, <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15-eq697.png\"></span> and <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15-eq698.png\"></span>, <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15-eq699.png\"></span>, for the models W1 and W2, respectively. By including family sample 2 (secure multiple images with unknown redshift), the statistical uncertainties on <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>w</i></span> is <span class=\"simple-math\">&#8776;</span>20<span class=\"simple-math\">%</span> smaller, but that on <span class=\"simple-math\">&#937;<sub>m</sub></span> increases by <span class=\"simple-math\">&#8776;</span>14<span class=\"simple-math\">%</span>. This is caused by a tilt in the orientation of the degeneracy between these two parameters. </p>\n<p>\n          <a name=\"F14\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table><tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/F14.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15-fig14_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/F14.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 11</span></a>\n              <p>Confidence regions of the free parameters in the model considering all multiple image families and varying <span class=\"simple-math\">&#937;<sub>m</sub></span> and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>w</i></span> in a flat Universe (model W2). The contours represent the <span class=\"simple-math\">68%</span>, <span class=\"simple-math\">95.4%</span>, and <span class=\"simple-math\">99.7%</span> confidence levels. The lines indicate the maximum likelihood in the projection on each single parameter. Contours associated with constrained redshifts are omitted for clarity.</p>\n            </td>\n</tr></table></div>\n        </p>\n<p>It appears that the extra information included in the additional multiple image families leads to an improvement of the overall model, i.e. to smaller errors on the values of the lens mass distribution parameters and, consequently, of the cosmological parameters. The 68%, 95.4% and 99.7% confidence regions on the cosmological parameter plane are shown in the top panels of Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#F13\">10</a>, for the models W1 and W2, respectively. The red contours indicate the confidence regions from the Planck satellite Data Release 2 (<a name=\"InR53\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R53\">Planck Collaboration XIII 2015</a>) and the blue regions show the combination with the likelihood from our strong lensing models. The agreement with the results from the CMB data, <span class=\"simple-math\">&#937;<sub>m</sub> = 0.3089 &#177; 0.0062</span> and <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15-eq701.png\"></span>, is very good (see Tables 4 and 5 in <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R53\">Planck Collaboration XIII 2015</a>), and we emphasize the complementarity of the two different cosmological probes, making their combination in principle powerful. </p>\n<p>In the bottom panels of Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#F13\">10</a>, we show the confidence regions of the cosmological parameters for the models L1 and L2 (<span class=\"simple-math\">&#937;<sub>m</sub></span> and <span class=\"simple-math\">&#937;<sub>&#923;</sub></span> free to vary and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>w</i> = &#8722;1</span>). Here, we find a clear degeneracy between the values of <span class=\"simple-math\">&#937;<sub>m</sub></span> and <span class=\"simple-math\">&#937;<sub>&#923;</sub></span>, with the value of <span class=\"simple-math\">&#937;<sub>m</sub></span> smaller than 0.7 at <span class=\"simple-math\">99.7%</span> confidence level and that of <span class=\"simple-math\">&#937;<sub>&#923;</sub></span> essentially unconstrained. Indeed, the results of the simulations performed by <a name=\"InR16\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R16\">Gilmore &amp; Natarajan (2009)</a> showed that the values of the family ratios of Eq. (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#FD9\">9</a>), predicted by strong lensing models, are not very sensitive to changes in the value of the dark energy density parameter. For the models L1 and L2, we obtain <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15-eq702.png\"></span>, <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15-eq703.png\"></span> and <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15-eq704.png\"></span>, <span class=\"img-inline\"><img src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15-eq705.png\"></span> (68% confidence level), respectively. </p>\n<p>In Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#F14\">11</a>, we show for the model ID W2 the correlation between the parameters describing the total mass distribution of the lens and those related to the cosmological model. The histograms represent the probability density distributions of each free parameter, marginalized over all the other parameters. For visualization clarity, we do not show the redshifts of families 9, 13, 15, 16, 17, 20 and 21 in this figure, although they are also free parameters (see the model ID W2 in Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#T5\">5</a>). </p>\n<p>Figure <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#F14\">11</a> shows that the cosmological parameters are mainly degenerate with the <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#963;</i><sub>v</sub></span> parameter, which is associated with the mass of the cluster dark matter halo: <span class=\"simple-math\">&#937;<sub>m</sub></span> and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#963;</i><sub>v</sub></span> are positively correlated, while <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>w</i></span> and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#963;</i><sub>v</sub></span> are strongly anti-correlated for low (<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>w</i>&lt; &#8722;1</span>) and high (<span class=\"simple-math\">&gt;</span>1500 km&#8201;s<span class=\"simple-math\"><sup>-1</sup></span>) values, respectively. This result suggests that independent information about the total mass of a cluster, for example from galaxy dynamics (e.g. <a name=\"InR6\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R6\">Biviano et al. 2013</a>) or weak lensing (e.g. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R71\">Umetsu et al. 2014</a>), could further reduce the statistical uncertainties on recovered cosmological parameters. It remains important however to consider the impact of a number of systematics inherent in different methods of mass measurements. </p>\n<p>In a previous work, <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R31\">Jullo et al. (2010)</a> studied the same cosmological model using the galaxy cluster Abell 1689, a merging cluster located at <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> = 0.184</span>. In that work, starting from a sample of 102 secure-spectroscopic multiple images, they considered a subsample of 28 multiple images from eight different families distributed in redshift between 1.50 and 3.05. Figure 2 of <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R31\">Jullo et al. (2010)</a> shows the confidence regions in the <span class=\"simple-math\">&#937;<sub>m</sub></span>-<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>w</i></span> plane, as obtained from their strong lensing analysis only and in combination with the results from CMB observations. Those results are qualitatively similar to our findings in Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#F13\">10</a>. Small differences in the confidence regions of the two studies can be ascribed to the different parametrization of the total mass of the clusters (including a careful selection of the cluster members in our model), the configuration of the adopted multiple images, the source and cluster redshifts, and the treatment of the positional errors of multiple images. </p>\n<p>To highlight the importance of having multiply lensed sources over a wide range of redshift when trying to constrain cosmological parameters, we also study specific models (W3 and L3 in Tables <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#T4\">4</a> and <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#T5\">5</a>) in which we exclude the family at the highest redshift, <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> = 6.111</span> (ID 14). In these models, the final positional <span class=\"simple-math\">&#916;<sub>rms</sub></span> remains basically unchanged when compared to models W2 and L2, however, the constraints on the cosmological parameters become much weaker, as shown in Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#F15\">12</a> (model W3/L3: left/right panel). Although the confidence regions of the lens mass distribution parameters increase by less than <span class=\"simple-math\">~</span>10<span class=\"simple-math\">%</span>, this high-redshift system has a significant leverage on the estimate of cosmological parameter. In this case, we find that the same confidence regions of <span class=\"simple-math\">&#937;<sub>m</sub></span> and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>w</i></span> increase by <span class=\"simple-math\">&#8776;</span>50<span class=\"simple-math\">%</span> from model W2 to W3 with <span class=\"simple-math\">&#937;<sub>m</sub></span> now becoming largely unconstrained. Such a deterioration is even more evident for model L3, when compared to L2. This test highlights the importance of probing the widest possible redshift range with spectroscopic multiply lensed systems, when exploring cosmography with strong lensing techniques. Similar results from cluster-scale strong lensing simulations were presented by <a name=\"InR19\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R19\">Golse et al. (2002)</a>, confirming the essential role played by spectroscopically confirmed systems over a large redshift range for accurate measurements of the values of the cosmological parameters. Finally, we mention that the models Wa1 and Wa2, which include a variation with redshift in the dark energy equation of state, can reproduce the observed multiple image positions only slightly better. This indicates very little sensitivity on the <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>w</i><sub><i>a</i></sub></span> parameter in our current strong lensing models of RXC J2248. </p>\n<h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"S16\"></a>5. Line-of-sight mass structure</h2>\n<p>To estimate the perturbing lensing effect of mass structures along the line of sight not included in the single-plane lens modelling of RXC J2248, we perform the following simplified tests with the <span class=\"smallcaps\">Glee </span>software, developed by A. Halkola and S. H. Suyu (<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R64\">Suyu &amp; Halkola 2010</a>; <a name=\"InR66\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R66\">Suyu et al. 2012</a>). We mimic the strong lensing geometry observed in RXC J2248 as close as possible, both in terms of angular positions and redshifts of the multiple images. In detail, we consider eight different sources lensed into 24 multiple images, distributed within a circle of <span class=\"simple-math\">&#8776;</span>1<span class=\"simple-math\">&#8242;</span> in radius from the cluster centre and covering a redshift range between 1.0 and 6.1, thus following the observed configuration (see Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#T1\">1</a> and Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#F1\">1</a>). The starting <i>unperturbed </i>positions of the 24 images are perfectly fitted, i.e. with a null rms offset, by only one PIEMD mass profile, with parameter values very close to those shown in Table <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#T4\">4</a> and within a fixed cosmological model with <span class=\"simple-math\">&#937;<sub>m</sub> = 0.3</span>, <span class=\"simple-math\">&#937;<sub>&#923;</sub> = 0.7</span>, <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>w</i> = &#8722;1.0</span>, and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>H</i><sub>0</sub> = 70</span> km&#8201;s<span class=\"simple-math\"><sup>-1</sup></span>&#8201;Mpc<span class=\"simple-math\"><sup>-1</sup></span>. Then, we simulate plausible lens galaxies along the line of sight, modelled as dPIE mass distributions with vanishing ellipticity and core radius, introduce their mass components in the lensing model, and calculate the <i>perturbed </i>multiple image positions. We use these new positions as observables to optimize the parameters of the PIEMD mass profile, neglecting the contribution of the secondary line-of-sight deflectors. This should represent the typical lensing modelling situation in which the parameters describing the total mass distribution of a galaxy cluster, acting as a primary deflector on background sources, are measured by fitting the positions of a set of multiple images in the single-plane lens approximation, i.e. ignoring the effect of possible mass structures along the line of sight. </p>\n<p>\n        \n        <a name=\"F15\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table><tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/F15.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15-fig15_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/F15.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 12</span></a>\n            <p>Confidence regions on the cosmological parameter planes when all multiple image systems are used with the exception of the highest redshift (<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>z</i> = 6.111</span>) family (<i>left</i>: model W3; <i>right</i>: model L3).</p>\n          </td>\n</tr></table></div>\n      </p>\n<p>\n        \n        <a name=\"F16\"></a><div class=\"inset\"><table><tr>\n<td valign=\"middle\"><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/F16.html\" target=\"_blank\"><img alt=\"thumbnail\" src=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15-fig16_small.jpg\"></a></td>\n<td class=\"img-txt\">\n<a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/F16.html\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"bold\">Fig. 13</span></a>\n            <p><i>Left</i><i> panel</i>: probability distribution function, obtained from the set of 20 simulations, of the <span class=\"simple-math\">&#916;<sub>rms</sub></span> offset between the perturbed and best-fitting model-predicted positions of the 24 multiple images. The predicted positions are determined by optimizing the parameters of the total mass distribution of the main lens not including the mass perturbers along the line-of-sight. <i>Middle and right panels</i>: best-fitting values of the parameters <span class=\"simple-math\">&#937;<sub>m</sub></span>, <span class=\"simple-math\">&#937;<sub>&#923;</sub></span> and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>w</i></span> from the set of 20 simulations. These values are determined by optimizing the parameters of the total mass distribution of the main lens and of the cosmological model not including in the mass perturbers along the line-of-sight.</p>\n          </td>\n</tr></table></div>\n      </p>\n<p>Initially, we add a single dPIE perturber to the PIEMD mass component. We fix the values of its distance from the cluster centre and effective velocity dispersion to 60 arcsec and 200 km&#8201;s<span class=\"simple-math\"><sup>-1</sup></span>, respectively. We then vary the redshift value of the dPIE component from 0.05 to 0.65 with a constant step of 0.1. To obtain non-negligible perturbing lensing effects, we purposely simulate such a massive galaxy, close in projection to the Einstein radius of the cluster for the source at the highest redshift. The optimized PIEMD mass models (without varying the cosmological parameters) can reproduce the perturbed multiple-image positions with <span class=\"simple-math\">&#916;<sub>rms</sub></span> values that range from 0.3 to 0.1 arcsec, decreasing systematically with the redshift of the perturber. This simple test confirms the results of previous studies (e.g. <a name=\"InR43\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R43\">McCully et al. 2014</a>) which have shown that statistically, at fixed total mass values, mass concentrations in the foreground of a main deflector affect the lensed positions of the multiple images more significantly than mass concentrations in the background. We remark that massive foreground or member galaxies are rarely omitted in the lensing model of a galaxy cluster because these galaxies are usually very luminous and easily identified as important lensing components (e.g. see Sect. 3.4 in <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R23\">Grillo et al. 2015b</a>). Therefore, rms values of 0.3 arcsec or larger associated with only one massive and neglected line-of-sight structure are not very likely in detailed strong lensing models. </p>\n<p>Next, we consider a set of 20 more realistic simulations, each of which containing ten different dPIE mass components. The position and mass parameters of these components are extracted from uniform distributions in the following ranges: mass centres, in angular coordinates <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>x</i></span> and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>y</i></span> from the cluster centre, between <span class=\"simple-math\">&#8722;60</span> and <span class=\"simple-math\">60</span> arcsec, redshift values between 0 and 0.8, and effective velocity dispersion values between 25 and 175 km&#8201;s<span class=\"simple-math\"><sup>-1</sup></span>. As above, for each simulation we optimize the PIEMD mass parameters, not modelling the perturbers and not changing the cosmological parameters, and estimate the rms offset <span class=\"simple-math\">&#916;</span> between the perturbed and model-predicted positions of the multiple images. The results are summarized in the first panel of Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#F16\">13</a>. The probability distribution function of <span class=\"simple-math\">&#916;</span> has mean and standard deviation values of 0.3 and 0.1 arcsec, respectively. An offset of approximately 0.3 arcsec in the reproduction of the observed multiple-image positions has been found in our best-fitting strong lensing models of RXC J2248 (see Sect. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#S12\">4</a>), MACS J0416 (e.g., see Sect. 3.5.1 in <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R23\">Grillo et al. 2015b</a>) and MACS J1149 (e.g. see Sect. 3.4 in  <a name=\"InR22\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R22\">Grillo et al. 2015a</a>), which have been obtained in the single-plane lens approximation, as in these simulations. Moreover, we investigate the systematic uncertainty on the values of the cosmological parameters introduced by neglecting the mass structure along the line of sight. To do so, we add the values of <span class=\"simple-math\">&#937;<sub>m</sub></span>, <span class=\"simple-math\">&#937;<sub>&#923;</sub></span>, and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>w</i></span> to the PIEMD mass parameters in the modelling optimization performed on the same sample of 20 sets of perturbed multiple-image positions. Allowing three additional (cosmological) parameters to vary leads to average <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>rms</i></span> values that are approximately <span class=\"simple-math\">10%</span> smaller than the previous values. We show the best-fitting values of <span class=\"simple-math\">&#937;<sub>m</sub></span>, <span class=\"simple-math\">&#937;<sub>&#923;</sub></span> and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>w</i></span> in the second and third panels of Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#F16\">13</a>, and estimate the median with standard deviation values of <span class=\"simple-math\">0.3  &#177;  0.1</span>, <span class=\"simple-math\">0.8  &#177;  0.1,</span> and <span class=\"simple-math\">&#8722;1.0  &#177;  0.1</span>, respectively. The comparison of Figs. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#F13\">10</a> and <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#F16\">13</a> suggests that the total (statistical+systematic) degeneracy between the values of <span class=\"simple-math\">&#937;<sub>m</sub></span> and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>w</i></span> is likely not driven by the systematic effect of the unmodelled line-of-sight mass structure. The results of Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#F14\">11</a> (in particular the <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>&#963;</i><sub>v</sub></span>-<span class=\"simple-math\"><i>w</i></span> panel) and Fig. <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#F16\">13</a> indicate that additional information about the total mass is needed from different diagnostics to reduce the uncertainties on the values of <span class=\"simple-math\">&#937;<sub>m</sub></span> and <span class=\"simple-math\"><i>w</i></span>. </p>\n<p>We caution that we obtained the previous results through simplified total mass models of a galaxy cluster that does not contain cluster members. We have purposely chosen this approach to reduce the degeneracies among the parameters describing the relative mass contributions of the cluster and cluster members and thus facilitate the interpretation of the test outcome. We postpone to a future work a more thorough analysis including the cluster members. The spectroscopic CLASH-VLT programme and additional VLT/MUSE follow-up campaigns (e.g. in RXC 2248, see <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R32\">Karman et al. 2015</a>; and in MACS J1149, see <a name=\"InR70\"></a><a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R70\">Treu et al. 2016</a> and <a href=\"/articles/aa/full_html/2016/03/aa27670-15/aa27670-15.html#R22\">Grillo et al. 2015a</a>) have identified the mass structures along the line of sight that should be incorporated in the ultimate strong lensing models of galaxy clusters. Unfortunately, at the time when this analysis was performed none of the lensing codes available could fully model line-of-sight mass structures and carefully quantify the impact of this effect on the reconstructed values of the cluster mass and cosmological parameters. The <span class=\"smallcaps\">Glee </span>software has recently been updated to include multiple plane lensing, which will be presented in future works. </p>\n<h2 class=\"sec\">\n<a name=\"S17\"></a>6.
